choices.text: Comma-shaped and grows well in high pH

questions.text: A 70-year-old diabetic woman comes to the physician complaining of progressive, severe pain and discharge from her left ear for the past 2 days. On examination, moving or touching the pinna produces extreme pain. Otoscopic examination shows granulation tissue in the left ear canal with a scant amount of discharge. Which of the following microbiological characteristics best describes the infecting organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile and oxidase positive

 

This elderly diabetic woman presents with malignant otitis externa, a severe infection of the external auditory canal often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The presence of granulation tissue in the ear canal is highly characteristic.
Pseudomonas is a Gram-negative rod, motile (flagella present), and oxidase positive. It thrives in moist environments and is notorious for causing infections in immunocompromised and diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Comma-shaped and grows well in high pH: This refers to Vibrio cholerae, which is comma-shaped, grows in alkaline pH, and causes watery diarrhea (rice-water stools), not ear infections.

 

Option B. Fast lactose fermenter: Organisms like Escherichia coli and Klebsiella are rapid lactose fermenters (pink colonies on MacConkey agar). They are common in urinary and gastrointestinal infections, not malignant otitis externa.

 

Option D. Nonmotile and a lactose nonfermenter: This describes Shigella species, which are nonmotile, non-lactose fermenters. They cause dysentery with blood and mucus in stools, not ear canal infections.

questions.text: Anti-larval measures are being taken for a pond in a city. Which of the following synthetic insecticides are not recommended for such measures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DDT

 

For anti-larval measures (vector control at the larval stage), larvicides are recommended. These include temephos (Abate), fenthion, and Paris green (copper acetoarsenite).

 

  • DDT is not used as a larvicide; it is an adulticide (kills adult mosquitoes) and is mainly applied in indoor residual spraying (IRS) for malaria control. Therefore, it is not recommended for larval control in ponds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fenthion: An organophosphorus insecticide that acts as a larvicide. Effective in stagnant water collections, especially for mosquito larval control.

 

Option B. Paris green: A copper acetoarsenite compound that has been historically used as a larvicide. It selectively kills mosquito larvae on water surfaces.

 

Option D. Abate (Temephos): An organophosphate widely used as a safe and effective mosquito larvicide, recommended by WHO for potable water sources.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of severe dengue?

 

  1. AST and ALT are more than 1000 IU
  2. Hepatomegaly >1cm
  3. Leucopenia plus thrombocytopenia
  4. Severe bleeding 
  5. Vomiting
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

  • Severe plasma leakage → leading to shock or respiratory distress
  • Severe bleeding → as evaluated clinically
  • Severe organ impairment → e.g., liver (AST/ALT >1000 IU/L), CNS involvement, heart or other organ failure

So:

  • (1) AST/ALT >1000 IU → severe organ involvement
  • (4) Severe bleeding → hallmark of severe dengue

questions.text: Under NVBDCP, the drug combination shown below can be given under which dose combination?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 80 mg, 480 mg

 

According to National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) guidelines, the combination of Artemether and Lumefantrine (as shown in the image) is given in the dose of 80 mg Artemether and 480 mg Lumefantrine for adults (body weight >34 kg), administered as 4 tablets (each 20 mg/120 mg) twice daily for 3 days. Hence, Option A (80mg, 480mg) is correct, used for treatment of Uncomplicated Malaria by Plasmodium falciparum in NORTH EASTERN STATES of INDIA.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Artemether: A fast-acting artemisinin derivative → rapidly kills malaria parasites (including gametocytes).
  • Lumefantrine: A longer-acting antimalarial → prevents recrudescence by killing remaining parasites.

 

Note: First-Line Treatment of Uncomplicated P. falciparum Malaria (India, NVBDCP):

 

 

Additional Points:

 

  • Primaquine (single dose) is added in all regions to clear gametocytes and prevent transmission.
  • Severe malaria (all over India): IV Artesunate is the drug of choice.

questions.text: Identify the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endemic typhus

 

  • The image shows a flea (reddish-brown, wingless insect with laterally compressed body).
  • Fleas are the vectors of several zoonotic diseases.
  • Specifically, Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) transmits Rickettsia typhi → causes Endemic (Murine) Typhus.
  • Reservoir: rodents (rats).
  • Transmission: flea bite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidemic typhus:

 

  • Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.
  • Vector = human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis), not fleas.

 

Option C. Q fever:

 

  • Caused by Coxiella burnetii.
  • No arthropod vector; transmitted via inhalation of aerosols from infected animals (placenta, urine, feces).

 

Option D. Scrub typhus:

 

  • Caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.
  • Vector = trombiculid mite (chigger mite), not fleas.

choices.text: Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of anti-fever therapy
Minimum of three days after recovery from shock

questions.text: Criteria for discharging patients of dengue includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Platelet count of more than 20,000/mm³ 

 

Because 20,000/mm³ is too low — it is still considered a high-risk stage.

 

The WHO discharge criteria for dengue patients include:

 

  • No fever for at least 24–48 hours without antipyretics.
  • Improvement in clinical status (well-being, appetite, urine output).
  • Stable hematocrit without intravenous fluids.
  • Stable vital signs for at least 24 hours.
  • Platelet count >50,000/mm³ (not just 20,000).
  • 2–3 days after recovery from shock

choices.text: Most effective method of malarial control is personal protection
Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) should be provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index ≥ 5.
Indoor Residual Sprays are useful in rural areas.
In case of DDT resistance, 3 rounds of spraying with Malathion should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season.

questions.text: All of the following are true about NVBDCP except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most effective method of malarial control is personal protection

 

  • In the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP), the most effective method of malaria control is vector control through Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS) and Long Lasting Insecticidal Nets (LLINs) — not just “personal protection” like mosquito repellents or coils.
  • Personal protection measures (repellents, nets without insecticide, coils, etc.) are helpful but not the most effective on a community/public health scale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLIN) should be provided in areas with Annual Parasite Index ≥ 5: Correct. LLIN distribution is targeted to high transmission areas (API ≥ 5 or tribal/hard-to-reach populations).

 

Option C. Indoor Residual Sprays are useful in rural areas: Correct. IRS with DDT, Malathion, or Synthetic pyrethroids is mainly done in rural malaria endemic areas, especially during transmission season.

 

Option D. In case of DDT resistance, 3 rounds of spraying with Malathion should be done to provide protection during the entire transmission season: Correct. this is NVBDCP recommendation. Malathion (or synthetic pyrethroids) are used when DDT resistance is documented.

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in medicine ward with fever. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

The figure shown is the timeline of leptospirosis infection:

 

  • Incubation: 2–20 days.
  • Acute (septicemic) phase (Week 1):
    • Sudden fever, myalgia.
    • Antigen present in blood/CSF.
    • Culture possible from blood/CSF.
  • Convalescent (immune) phase (Week 2–3):
    • Fever may relapse.
    • Antigen found in urine.
    • Culture possible from urine.
    • Antibody titers start rising (detectable by serology).
  • Complications: Uveitis, interstitial nephritis, reservoir host state.
  • Serology: Antibody titers rise in Week 2, remain high for months–years, then decline gradually.
  • Investigations:
    • Early = culture from blood/CSF.
    • Later = urine culture + serology (e.g., MAT, ELISA IgM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebral malaria: Presents acutely with altered sensorium, parasitemia in blood smear, no biphasic antigen/antibody pattern.

 

Option C. Brucellosis: Incubation longer (2–8 weeks), usually chronic undulant fever, not this biphasic blood→urine antigen pattern.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Step-ladder fever, rose spots, antigen detection mainly in blood during 1st week (Widal serology later), but no urinary phase or prolonged antibody persistence as shown.

choices.text: The elementary body is the infectious form of the causative organism.
Applying erythromycin to the newborn's eyes prevents the disease.
Infection in pregnant women is treated with doxycycline.
Genital disease is caused by serotypes A, B, and C

questions.text: A 31-year-old pregnant lady comes with dysuria and urethral discharge for 3 days. NAAT for gonorrhea was negative. What is the true statement regarding the condition the patient is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The elementary body is the infectious form of the causative organism.

 

Diagnosis of the condition:

 

  • A 31-year-old pregnant lady with dysuria + urethral discharge → classically points toward sexually transmitted infection (STI).
  • Gonorrhea (caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae) is a common cause of urethritis.
  • But here, NAAT for gonorrhea is negative → so gonorrhea is ruled out.
  • The most likely cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars D–K).

 

About Chlamydia:

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis has a biphasic life cycle.
  • Elementary body (EB): small, metabolically inactive, extracellular, infectious form.
  • Reticulate body (RB): intracellular, metabolically active, replicative form.
  • Since the patient is pregnant, the most likely cause of non-gonococcal urethritis is Chlamydia (serotypes D–K), and EB is the infectious stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Applying erythromycin to the newborn's eyes prevents the disease: Incorrect. 

 

  • Topical erythromycin ointment prevents gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum, not chlamydial.
  • Chlamydial conjunctivitis in newborns requires systemic oral therapy (erythromycin or azithromycin).

 

Option C. Infection in pregnant women is treated with doxycycline: Incorrect. 

 

  • Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy due to risk of fetal bone and teeth abnormalities.
  • Safe alternatives: Azithromycin (single dose) or Amoxicillin.

 

Option D. Genital disease is caused by serotypes A, B, and C:  Incorrect.

  • A–C → trachoma (ocular disease).
  • D–K → urogenital infections (urethritis, cervicitis, PID).
  • L1–L3 → lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)

questions.text: Which characteristic forms the basis for categorizing streptococci according to the Lancefield system?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C-substance

 

  • The Lancefield classification system groups β-hemolytic streptococci into serogroups (A, B, C… up to V) based on the carbohydrate antigen present in the bacterial cell wall.
  • This carbohydrate antigen is called the C-substance (C-carbohydrate).
  • Example:
    • Group A = Streptococcus pyogenes
    • Group B = Streptococcus agalactiae

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycoprotein O:

 

  • Not related to Lancefield classification.
  • Glycoproteins may play a role in bacterial adhesion but not in streptococcal grouping.

 

Option C. Muramic acid: 

 

  • A universal component of peptidoglycan cell walls in all bacteria, not specific to streptococci.
  • Hence, not used for classification.

 

Option D. M-protein:

 

  • A major virulence factor of Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Helps in resistance to phagocytosis and associated with rheumatic fever.
  • Important for typing within Group A streptococci, but not the basis of Lancefield grouping.

questions.text:
Identify the correct agent-disease pairings from the list provided:

 

  1. Lyme disease — Borrelia burgdorferi
  2. Cat-scratch disease — Bartonella henselae
  3. Glanders — Burkholderia mallei
  4. Rat bite fever — Borrelia recurrentis
  5. Trench fever — Bartonella bacilliformis
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

  • Statement 1. Lyme disease — Borrelia burgdorferi:
    • Transmitted by Ixodes tick.
    • Characterized by erythema migrans, arthritis, neurologic and cardiac manifestations.
  • Statement 2. Cat-scratch disease — Bartonella henselae:
    • Transmitted by cat scratches or bites.
    • Presents with regional lymphadenitis.
  • Statement 3. Glanders — Burkholderia mallei:
    • Zoonosis acquired from horses.
    • Rare, but causes pneumonia, septicemia, and cutaneous lesions.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 4. Rat bite fever — Borrelia recurrentis:

 

  • Rat bite fever is caused by:
    • Spirillum minus (Asia, “sodoku”) OR
    • Streptobacillus moniliformis (USA).
  • Borrelia recurrentis causes Louse-borne relapsing fever, not rat-bite fever.

 

Statement 5. Trench fever — Bartonella bacilliformis:

 

  • Trench fever = Bartonella quintana, transmitted by body louse.
  • Bartonella bacilliformis causes Oroya fever (Carrion’s disease) in South America.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hookworm infection

 

  • The image shows a serpiginous, erythematous, pruritic track on the foot → classic for cutaneous larva migrans.
  • Caused by dog/cat hookworms (Ancylostoma braziliense, Ancylostoma caninum).
  • Humans are accidental hosts; larvae penetrate skin but cannot complete lifecycle, so they migrate in the epidermis → “creeping eruption.”
  • Very common in barefoot walkers on sandy beaches or soil contaminated with dog/cat feces.
  • NOTE: Ancylostoma duodenale doesn’t cause Cutaneous Larva Migrans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brown recluse spider bite: Causes necrotic ulcer with central eschar and systemic symptoms, not a serpiginous creeping eruption.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium marinum infection:

 

  • Causes fish tank granuloma → nodular skin lesions on extremities after exposure to contaminated water.
  • Lesions follow a sporotrichoid pattern, not serpiginous tracks.

 

Option D. Sporothrix schenckii infection: 

 

  • Causes sporotrichosis (“rose gardener’s disease”).
  • Characterized by nodular lymphangitis (subcutaneous nodules spreading along lymphatics), not migrating serpiginous lesions.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to skin lesions on her trunk and proximal upper limbs. The patient noticed the lesions after returning from a summer vacation at a Goa beach a week ago. During the vacation, she had sun exposure on several occasions without prior application of sunscreen. The lesions are mildly itchy but not painful. Medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malassezia globosa infection

 

  • The image shows hypopigmented, scaly macules and patches on the trunk, commonly seen after sun exposure.
  • This is classic for Tinea versicolor (Pityriasis versicolor), caused by the lipophilic yeast Malassezia globosa (previously M. furfur).
  • Lesions are hypopigmented or hyperpigmented due to fungal interference with melanin production.
  • Mild itching may be present, especially after sweating or heat exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune melanocyte injury:

 

  • Refers to vitiligo.
  • Produces depigmented (chalk-white), well-demarcated macules, not scaly patches.
  • Vitiligo is non-pruritic and progressive, not linked to sun/heat exposure.

 

 

Option B. Dermatophyte skin infection:

 

  • Dermatophytes (Trichophyton, Microsporum, Epidermophyton) cause ringworm (tinea corporis).
  • Lesions are annular, erythematous, scaly patches with central clearing, not hypopigmented diffuse patches like in this case.

 

 

Option D. Ultraviolet skin damage:

 

  • Sunburn causes erythema, pain, blistering.
  • Chronic UV exposure causes photoaging and actinic keratoses, not multiple hypopigmented macules.

choices.text: The organism is tube coagulase positive
On culture, golden yellow pigments are produced on nutrient agar
Beta-hemolysis is seen on blood agar

questions.text: Gram staining from pus of a 30 year old with chronic osteomyelitis is shown. Identify the incorrect statement about the causative organism:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The organism is catalase negative

 

  • The image shows Gram-positive cocci in clusters, classic for Staphylococcus aureus.
  • S. aureus is the most common cause of chronic osteomyelitis.
  • Biochemical features:
    • Catalase positive (distinguishes staphylococci from streptococci).
    • Coagulase positive (tube coagulase test).
    • Produces golden-yellow colonies on nutrient agar due to carotenoid pigment (staphyloxanthin).
    • Causes β-hemolysis on blood agar.
  • Hence, saying “catalase negative” is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The organism is tube coagulase positive: Correct. S. aureus is the only staphylococcus that is tube coagulase positive.

 

Option C. On culture, golden yellow pigments are produced on nutrient agar: Correct. Pigment = staphyloxanthin, gives colonies a golden color.

 

Option D. Beta-hemolysis is seen on blood agar: Correct. S. aureus produces clear zones of β-hemolysis

questions.text: Which of the following tests is a type of ring precipitation test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ascoli's thermoprecipitation test

 

  • Ascoli’s thermoprecipitation test is a ring precipitation test used for the diagnosis of anthrax.
  • Principle: Precipitin lines (ring formation) appear at the junction of antigen and antibody solutions in a test tube.
  • It detects anthrax antigens in tissues or hides of infected animals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VDRL test:

 

  • A flocculation test, not a precipitation test.
  • Detects reagin antibodies in syphilis using cardiolipin antigen.

 

Option B. Rose Bengal test:

 

  • A slide agglutination test for brucellosis.
  • Uses stained Brucella antigen to detect antibodies.

 

 

Option D. Elek test:

 

  • An in vitro toxigenicity test for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Based on immunodiffusion in agar (precipitin lines form in agar plate), not a ring precipitation in liquid.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with severe pain in his gums, foul breath, and bleeding during brushing for the past week. On examination, his gingivae are red, edematous, and covered with ulcers and a necrotic membrane. The patient reports poor oral hygiene and stress due to a recent workload increase. Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fusiform bacilli 

 

  • Vincent’s angina, also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis (ANUG), is caused by a synergistic infection of Fusiform bacilli and Borrelia vincenti. 
  • It is characterized by painful, ulcerative lesions on the gingivae with necrotic membrane formation. 
  • Risk factors include poor oral hygiene, stress, and immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus mutans: This organism is primarily associated with dental caries and not necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis.

 

Option C. Actinomyces israelii: This bacterium is the causative agent of actinomycosis, which typically presents as chronic, suppurative infections, often with draining sinuses.

 

Option D. Treponema pallidum: This organism causes syphilis, characterized by painless chancres and systemic manifestations, but not gingival necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vincent's angina (acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis) is caused by Fusiform bacilli and Borrelia vincenti and presents with painful gingival ulcers, necrotic membranes, and foul breath.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with a history of chronic smoking presented with fever, confusion, diarrhea and cough. Chest X-ray revealed bilateral infiltrates. Gram stain, immunofluorescence testing was done on sputum sample and came negative for organisms. Serology findings are given below. Which of the following organisms is responsible for this presentation?

 

Serum Na+ – 120 meq/L

 

AST – 62 IU/L

 

ALT – 56 IU/L

 

HIV – Positive
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Legionella

 

 Diagnosis from Clinical Clues:

 

  • Elderly chronic smoker → high risk for atypical pneumonia.
  • Symptoms: fever, confusion, diarrhoea, cough → classic for Legionnaires’ disease.
  • Chest X-ray: bilateral infiltrates.
  • Lab findings:
    • Hyponatremia (Na+ 120) → hallmark feature of Legionella.
    • Mildly elevated AST/ALT → commonly seen.
  • HIV positive → immunocompromised host, poses further risk.
  • Sputum stain & culture negative → Legionella does not grow on standard media; requires BCYE agar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus (S. pneumoniae): 

 

  • Causes lobar pneumonia with productive cough and positive Gram stain (Gram-positive diplococci).
  • Does not cause hyponatremia or diarrhoea.

 

Option C. Klebsiella:

 

  • Causes currant-jelly sputum, mainly in alcoholics and diabetics.
  • Shows Gram-negative bacilli on stain; not negative like here.

 

Option D. Pneumocystis carinii (jirovecii) pneumonia:

 

  • Common in HIV patients with CD4 <200.
  • Presents with subacute dyspnoea, dry cough, hypoxemia; CXR shows ground-glass opacities, not diarrhoea or hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with 2 days of fever, cough, sore throat, and runny nose comes to the OPD. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation. A nasopharyngeal swab is obtained. Naked viral particles are seen, and purified RNA molecules are extracted from these particles. Once introduced into human cells, the purified RNA molecules induce viral protein synthesis and viral genome replication. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rhinovirus

 

Lets diagnose from clinical vignette given:

 

  • Young man with fever, cough, sore throat, runny nose → features of an upper respiratory tract infection (common cold).
  • Clear lungs → rules out pneumonia.
  • Naked viral particles → excludes enveloped viruses.
  • Purified RNA alone is infectious → this means the virus is a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus (ssRNA+) because it can directly act as mRNA in host cells.
  • Rhinovirus (Picornavirus family) fits best.
  • Picornavirus; naked, positive-sense ssRNA.
  • Purified RNA is infectious (directly acts as mRNA).
  • Causes common cold with nasal symptoms, mild fever, sore throat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIV:

 

  • Retrovirus; enveloped, not naked.
  • RNA genome requires reverse transcriptase before protein synthesis → purified RNA alone is not infectious.

 

Option B. Influenza virus type A: 

 

  • Orthomyxovirus; enveloped, segmented negative-sense RNA.
  • Needs viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase; purified RNA alone is not infectious.

 

Option C. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV):

 

  • Paramyxovirus; enveloped, negative-sense RNA.
  • Requires polymerase; purified RNA is not infectious.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 2 days of fever and a lesion on his right foot. The initial lesion was erythematous and oedematous, but it quickly developed into a bulla surrounded by erythema. Eventually, the bulla ruptured, leaving a painless ulcer with a black centre. The patient has a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and recently underwent chemotherapy. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient's foot lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antipseudomonal penicillin

 

Step 1: Diagnosis from Clinical Clues:

 

  • Patient: immunocompromised (non-Hodgkin lymphoma, chemotherapy).
  • Lesion evolution: erythematous → edematous → bulla → ruptured ulcer with black necrotic center.
  • This is classic for Ecthyma gangrenosum, most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • These necrotic skin ulcers are strongly associated with bacteremia in neutropenic/chemotherapy patients.

 

Step 2: Treatment:

 

  • Requires antipseudomonal coverage (e.g., piperacillin-tazobactam, ceftazidime, cefepime, imipenem, meropenem).
  • Therefore, D) Antipseudomonal penicillin is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salvage chemotherapy: Irrelevant here; underlying lymphoma is not the acute problem.

 

Option B. Corticosteroids: Would worsen infection by further immunosuppression.

 

Option C. Antistaphylococcal penicillin:

 

  • Covers MSSA (e.g., oxacillin, nafcillin), not Pseudomonas.
  • Wrong choice because the lesion is typical for Pseudomonas, not staph.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) River blindness: Deerfly

 

  • River blindness (Onchocerciasis) is caused by Onchocerca volvulus and transmitted by the blackfly (Simulium), not the deerfly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calabar swellings : Chrysops: Correct. Loa loa filariasis is spread by Chrysops (mango/deer fly), producing localized angioedema called Calabar swellings.

 

Option C. Sleeping sickness : Tse tse fly: Correct. Trypanosoma brucei gambiense/rhodesiense is transmitted by the tsetse fly (Glossina), causing African sleeping sickness.

 

Option D. Chagas disease : Reduvid bug: Correct. Trypanosoma cruzi is transmitted by the reduviid (kissing) bug), causing Chagas disease in South America.

questions.text:
Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores?

 

1. Glutaraldehyde

2. Ethylene oxide

3. Pasteurization

4. Orthophthalaldehyde
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

  • Statement 1. Glutaraldehyde (2%): High-level disinfectant, can achieve sterilization and kill spores if items are immersed long enough (≥10 hours).
  • Statement 2. Ethylene oxide: Gas sterilization method, penetrates well and kills spores; used for heat/moisture-sensitive instruments.
  • Statement  4. Orthophthalaldehyde (OPA): High-level disinfectant, similar to glutaraldehyde, and effective against spores with prolonged exposure.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

  • Statement  3. Pasteurization: Only kills vegetative bacteria and some viruses; does not kill spores (reason milk is not sterile after pasteurization).

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

 

  • Xenodiagnosis = diagnostic method where a live vector/insect is used to detect the pathogen by allowing it to feed on, or be inoculated with, patient material.
  • In dengue, suspected patient’s blood can be injected into the thorax of Aedes mosquitoes, then the mosquito is later tested for viral growth.
  • This is a classic example of a xenodiagnostic method in arboviruses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop for ETEC: Pathogenicity test for enterotoxin production, not xenodiagnosis.

 

Option C. Injecting hamster with splenic biopsy for leishmaniasis: This is an animal inoculation method, but not strictly xenodiagnosis (since no vector is involved). Traditionally, xenodiagnosis for leishmaniasis uses sandflies, not hamsters.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for diphtheria toxigenicity: In vivo test for toxin activity, not xenodiagnosis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the office due to a week of low-grade fever, dry cough, and right-sided chest pain. The pain is intermittent, sharp, and worse with deep inhalation or cough. The patient also notes mild "achiness" in his knees and ankles that started around the same time. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. The patient is an Army officer, and he returned after completing desert training exercises in Rajasthan. He does not know if other participants developed similar symptoms. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100 °F). Blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 16/min. Lung auscultation shows right-sided crackles. No joint swelling or tenderness is present, but there are erythematous, tender nodules on the bilateral shins. Chest x-ray reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate with a prominent right hilum. Which of the following is most likely causing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coccidioides immitis

 

  • The patient is an Army officer returning from desert training in Rajasthan → exposure to arid soil endemic fungi.
  • Presents with:
    • Low-grade fever, pleuritic chest pain, dry cough → pulmonary involvement.
    • Arthralgia (“desert rheumatism”) and erythema nodosum on shins → classic hypersensitivity findings.
    • CXR: unilateral lower lobe infiltrate + hilar adenopathy.
  • These features are typical of primary pulmonary coccidioidomycosis, caused by Coccidioides immitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomyces dermatitidis: 

 

  • Endemic to Mississippi & Ohio River valleys, Great Lakes.
  • Causes pneumonia with skin/bone involvement, not linked to desert regions like Rajasthan.

 

Option C. Histoplasma capsulatum: 

 

  • Endemic to Ohio & Mississippi River valleys.
  • Associated with bat/bird droppings (caves, chicken coops).
  • In India, histoplasmosis is rare and not desert-related.

 

Option D. Legionella pneumophila:

 

  • Causes atypical pneumonia with high fever, diarrhea, hyponatremia.
  • Spread via contaminated water (air conditioning, plumbing), not desert soil.
  • Does not cause erythema nodosum.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

A) Balamuthia mandrillaris → Pseudopodia (3)

 

  • A free-living amoeba causing granulomatous amebic encephalitis.
  • Amoebae move using pseudopodia.

 

B) Balantidium coli → Cilia (2)

 

  • The only ciliate protozoan infecting humans.
  • Moves and feeds with cilia.

 

C) Trichomonas vaginalis → Flagella (1)

 

  • Urogenital protozoan parasite.
  • Motility via flagella.

 

D) Toxoplasma gondii → No particular locomotory organ (4)

 

  • An apicomplexan parasite.
  • Has no locomotory organelle; moves via gliding mechanism using apical complex.

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravid woman at 8 weeks gestation comes to the office for her initial prenatal visit. She has no symptoms except mild nausea. She smoked a pack of cigarettes a day and drank 7-8 beers each week but quit after learning she was pregnant. The patient has a history of an allergic reaction to penicillin; she developed a generalized rash with intense itching that responded to antihistamines and corticosteroid cream. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The screening VDRL test is positive, fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test is positive. Her HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skin testing and penicillin desensitization

 

  • The patient is pregnant and has confirmed syphilis (VDRL + FTA-ABS positive).
  • The only proven therapy for syphilis in pregnancy is penicillin G, which prevents congenital syphilis.
  • Since she has a history of penicillin allergy, the 
  • If positive → penicillin desensitization, followed by recommended management is:
    1. Skin testing for penicillin allergy, and
    2. treatment with penicillin G.
  • Alternative antibiotics (eg, doxycycline, azithromycin) are not reliable in pregnancy and do not adequately protect the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Azithromycin:

 

  • Has been studied but resistance is common.
  • Not recommended in pregnancy for syphilis.

 

Options B. Doxycycline: Contraindicated in pregnancy (ADR: tooth discoloration, bone effects).

 

Options C. No treatment until delivery. Detrimental to fetus. Increases risk of congenital syphilis with severe neonatal complications (Triad of stillbirth, Hutchinson’s teeth, saddle nose).

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿The entire life cycle takes about 15 days
﻿﻿﻿Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

 

  • The image shows Sarcoptes scabiei, the mite that causes scabies.
  • Clinical picture: intense nocturnal pruritus, papules/plaques in finger web spaces, groin, inframammary folds → classic scabies.
  • Life cycle facts:
    • Life history has 4 stages: egg → larva → nymph → adult. [option A]
    • Larva has 3 pairs of legs, whereas nymphs/adults have 4 pairs. [option B]
    • Entire life cycle on human skin takes about 10–14 days (≈15 days). [option C]
    • Female mite burrows into the stratum corneum to lay eggs.[option D]
    • Male mite does not burrow; it dies after fertilizing the female on the skin surface.

choices.text: Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

questions.text:
6-hour-old boy is being evaluated in the nursery. He was born at 39 weeks’ gestation via spontaneous vagina delivery to a 33-year-old primigravida. The pregnancy was complicated by intravenous drug use. First trimester serologies, including RPR, HIV antibodies, and hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), were negative. Due to the mother's risk profile, follow up testing was obtained during the third trimester and revealed the following lab values: 

 

HBSAg - Positive

Anti-HBsAg - Negative

IgM Anti-HBcAg - Negative

Anti-HBcAg - Positive

Anti HCV - Negative

Liver function testing was normal. The remainder of the

pregnancy was uncomplicated. The infant weighs 3.7 kg (8 lb 3 oz). Physical examination of the infant is normal. There is no jaundice or hepatomegaly. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

 

  • Mother’s serology:
    • HBsAg-positive → she is infectious.
    • Anti-HBs negative → no protective immunity.
    • Anti-HBc IgM negative, Anti-HBc positive → indicates chronic carrier state, not acute infection.
    • Infant of an HBsAg-positive mother must receive:
    • Hepatitis B vaccine (active immunization)
    • Hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG, passive immunization)
  • Both should be given within 12 hours of birth at different injection sites → provides the best protection against vertical transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer hepatitis B immune globulin: Incomplete. HBIG alone is not sufficient → baby still needs active immunity.

 

Option C. Administer hepatitis B vaccine: Incomplete. Vaccine alone provides delayed protection; baby needs immediate protection via HBIG.

 

Option D. Obtain hepatitis B antibody panel: Not necessary now. The diagnosis in the mother is clear; newborn must receive post-exposure prophylaxis immediately, not wait for testing.

questions.text: A 13-month-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of a painless, non-itchy rash that began this morning. The boy had a fever over the past 3 days, but it resolved on its own today. He takes no medications and his vaccinations are up to date. Examination shows a well-appearing infant with blanching, pink macules on his neck, back, abdomen, and chest. No vesicles are present. The rest of his examination is normal. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human herpesvirus 6

 

  • The child had high fever for 3 days, which suddenly resolved, followed by appearance of a blanching, pink maculopapular rash starting on the trunk and neck.
  • This is classic for Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum, sixth disease), caused by HHV-6 (sometimes HHV-7).
  • Age group: typically infants 6–18 months.
  • The child appears well despite rash, which is another key clue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coxsackievirus A:

 

  • Causes hand-foot-mouth disease.
  • Painful oral ulcers + vesicular rash on palms/soles, not trunk-only maculopapular rash.

 

Option C. Measles virus:

 

  • Causes fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, followed by cephalocaudal maculopapular rash.
  • Rash is not limited to trunk and doesn’t appear after fever subsides.

 

Option D. Parvovirus B19: 

 

  • Causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease).
  • Classic “slapped-cheek” rash with lacy reticular rash on extremities, not trunk-first rash.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the office due to a flu like illness with low-grade fever, malaise, nausea, and anorexia. The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She occasionally smokes marijuana and has used injection drugs in the past. She has had several sexual partners. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 121/78 mmHg, and pulse is 86/min. The patient has scleral icterus. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are as follows:

Total bilirubin-44.8 mg/dL

Aspartate aminotransferase-11,222 U/L

Alanine aminotransferase-21,184 U/L

Hepatitis B surface antibody - Positive

Hepatitis B core antibody - Positive

Hepatitis B surface antigen - Negative

Hepatitis A IgM antibody - Positive

Hepatitis A lgG antibody - Negative

Hepatitis C antibody - Negative

After discussing the findings, the patient says she is worried that she may transmit the disease to her boyfriend. Which of the following interventions for the boyfriend is most likely to decrease his risk of disease acquisition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis A vaccination

 

  • Patient has:
    • AST & ALT extremely elevated (>10,000 U/L) → typical of acute viral hepatitis.
    • Serology:
      • HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive, Anti-HBc positive → past, resolved hepatitis B infection with immunity.
      • Hepatitis A IgM positive, IgG negative → indicates acute Hepatitis A infection.
  • Transmission: fecal–oral, not sexual like HBV/HIV.
  • Her boyfriend is at risk of acquiring Hepatitis A through close household/sexual contact.
  • Best prevention: administer Hepatitis A vaccine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barrier contraceptive use: Reduces risk of STIs (HIV, HBV, gonorrhea, etc.) but not effective for fecal–oral transmission of Hepatitis A.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B immune globulin: Unnecessary. Patient already cleared HBV and is immune (HBsAg negative, anti-HBs positive).

 

Option D. Hepatitis B vaccination: Also unnecessary; patient does not have active HBV infection, so no risk to her partner.

questions.text:
Identify the false statements:

  1. Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is diagnostic of Ehrlichia chaffeensis
  2. E6, E7 are targets of vaccine against HPV
  3. SARS CO-2 specimen handling for molecular testing needs BSL-2
  4. Peptostreptococcus causes scromboid fish poisoning
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 4

 

Statement 2. E6, E7 are targets of vaccine against HPV:

 

  • False. HPV vaccines (bivalent, quadrivalent, nonavalent) target the L1 capsid protein, not the oncoproteins E6 and E7.
  • E6 and E7 are virulence factors that inactivate p53 and Rb, but they are not vaccine targets.

 

Statement 4. Peptostreptococcus causes scombroid fish poisoning:

 

  • False. Scombroid poisoning is due to ingestion of histamine formed by bacterial decarboxylation of histidine in spoiled fish such as tuna or mackerel.
  • Caused by Morganella morganii, Klebsiella, Proteus, not Peptostreptococcus.

 

Correct statements:

 

Statement 1. Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is diagnostic of Ehrlichia chaffeensis: True. Ehrlichia chaffeensis infects monocytes and macrophages, forming intracytoplasmic inclusions called morulae.

 

Statement 3. SARS-CoV-2 specimen handling for molecular testing needs BSL-2

 

  • True. Routine diagnostic handling of respiratory samples for RT-PCR requires BSL-2 precautions.
  • Virus culture or propagation requires BSL-3.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the clinic with fever, exertional dyspnoea, and non productive cough for one week. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 3 years ago but has been asymptomatic since. He has not been taking his medications consistently. His temperature is 38.9 C (102 °F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min, and respirations are 28/min. The patient's pulse oximetry shows 80% on room air. With use of a 100% nonrebreather mask, his oxygen saturation increases to 92%.

Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin - 9.6 g/dL

 

Platelets - 120,000/mm³

 

Leukocytes - 8,000/mm³ (no bands)

 

Arterial blood gases on room air

 

pH - 7.45

 

PaO₂ - 54 mm Hg

 

PaCO₂ - 44 mm Hg

 

Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. His CD4 count is 190/mm³ and lactate dehydrogenase level is 400 U/L. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and corticosteroids

 

  • HIV patient with CD4 <200 and subacute fever, exertional dyspnea, dry cough plus diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates → classic for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP).
  • Lab findings: hypoxemia (PaO₂ = 54 mm Hg), elevated LDH → typical in PCP.
  • Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the drug of choice.
  • Adjunctive corticosteroids are indicated when there is significant hypoxemia:
    • PaO₂ <70 mm Hg on room air or
    • Alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient ≥35 mm Hg.
  • This patient qualifies → needs TMP-SMX plus corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiation of antiretroviral treatment: ART is essential but not started in acute PCP with severe illness until infection is stabilized, to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS).

 

Option B. Intravenous pentamidine and corticosteroids: Pentamidine is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate TMP-SMX. TMP-SMX is first-line.

 

Option D. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Correct drug, but corticosteroids must also be added here due to severe hypoxemia.

choices.text: Blunting of the villi in the duodenum and proximal jejunum
Extensive colonic injury with yellow-white adherent layer
Flask-shaped ulcerations in the cecum and ascending colon
Foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with abrupt-onset vomiting followed by frequent, large-volume, watery diarrhea for the last day. She has no prior medical conditions but has not received recommended vaccinations. Physical examination shows mild dehydration. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation throughout. Bowel sounds are increased. Polymerase chain reaction testing of the stool sample yields a virus with a segmented, double-stranded RNA genome. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blunting of the villi in the duodenum and proximal jejunum

 

  • Child with abrupt-onset vomiting, profuse watery diarrhea, no vaccinations → classic for rotavirus gastroenteritis.
  • Virology clue: segmented, double-stranded RNA genome = Reoviridae family → Rotavirus.
  • Pathology:
    • Rotavirus infects enterocytes of the duodenum and proximal jejunum.
    • Causes blunting of villi and loss of brush border enzymes → malabsorption and osmotic diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Extensive colonic injury with yellow-white adherent layer: Describes pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridioides difficile, not rotavirus.

 

Option C. Flask-shaped ulcerations in the cecum and ascending colon: Seen in Entamoeba histolytica infection, not viral diarrhea.

 

Option D. Foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria: Pathognomonic for Whipple disease (Tropheryma whipplei), not acute viral gastroenteritis.

questions.text: A technician wants to sterilize the material of the laboratory. Which of the following is a correct combination for him to use?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liquid paraffin: Hot air oven

 

  • Hot air oven (dry heat sterilization) is used for sterilizing oils, fats, powders, and paraffin.
    • Hot air oven (dry heat sterilization) operates at 160°C for 1 hour (or 170°C for 30 minutes).
  • Mechanism: oxidative damage and protein denaturation.
  • Suitable for materials that are moisture-sensitive or would be damaged by steam.
  • Examples sterilized by hot air oven:
    • Oils and fats (like liquid paraffin)
    • Powders (talc, starch)
    • Glassware (pipettes, Petri dishes, flasks)
    • Metal instruments (scalpels, scissors)

 

  • Therefore, sterilizing liquid paraffin with a hot air oven is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heat-sensitive vaccine – Pasteurisation:

 

  • Incorrect.Pasteurisation is used for milk, not vaccines.
  • Heat-sensitive vaccines are sterilized by membrane filtration, not by heat.

 

Option C. LSS medium – Autoclave: Incorrect. Löffler’s serum slope (LSS) medium contains serum which coagulates on heating. It is sterilized by inspiratory (fractional) sterilization/tyndallization, not autoclave.

 

Option D. Catgut sutures – Autoclave: Incorrect. Autoclaving destroys catgut. They are sterilized by radiation like gamma rays.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man develops dysuria and purulent urethral discharge following unprotected sex with a new partner. Nucleic acid amplification testing is positive for Neisseria gonorrhea infection. The patient develops antibody against the bacterial pili that enhance attachment to host cells. His symptoms resolve with adequate treatment. His partner does not receive treatment. Several weeks later, the patient develops N gonorrhoeae reinfection after repeat exposure to the same partner. Which of the following is the most likely reason for the lack of long-lasting immunity against the bacteria despite antibody formation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antigenic variation

 

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae frequently causes reinfections because it can change the structure of its surface antigens, particularly the pili and outer membrane proteins.
  • Although the patient forms antibodies against pili after the first infection, new infections occur because the organism undergoes antigenic variation → immune system does not recognize the altered pili.
  • This mechanism explains the lack of long-lasting immunity and why repeat infections are common even with the same partner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antigenic mimicry:

 

  • Occurs when microbial antigens resemble host antigens (eg, Streptococcus pyogenes M protein mimicking cardiac myosin in rheumatic fever).
  • Not the mechanism in gonorrhea reinfection.

 

Option C. Conjugative plasmid: Responsible for antibiotic resistance transfer, not immune evasion.

 

Option D. Low molecular weight antigen: Such antigens may be poorly immunogenic, but gonococcal pili are not low molecular weight antigens; the issue is variation, not weak immunogenicity.

questions.text: The organism whose life cycle is shown below is associated with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

  • The image shows the life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese liver fluke).
  • Key features from the diagram:
    • Eggs ingested by snail → cercariae released → encyst as metacercariae in freshwater fish → humans infected by eating undercooked fish.
    • Adult worms live in the biliary ducts of humans.
  • Chronic infection leads to recurrent pyogenic cholangitis, biliary stones, and increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC):

 

  • Associated with chronic Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, and aflatoxin exposure.
  • Not linked with Clonorchis infection.

 

Option C. Gastric carcinoma: Associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, chronic gastritis, nitrosamines, not liver flukes.

 

Option D. Bladder carcinoma: Specifically squamous cell carcinoma of bladder is associated with Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the OPD due to penile ulcers that appeared after unprotected sexual intercourse. Physical examination shows 3 subcentimeter ulcers on the penile shaft. Microscopic examination of a scraping from an ulcer base reveals the following. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir

 

  • The image shows multinucleated giant cells with ground-glass nuclei on Tzanck smear.
  • Clinical findings:
    • Painful penile ulcers appearing after unprotected sex.
    • Multiple, small ulcers with erythematous base.
  • This is classic for Genital herpes, caused by Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) (sometimes HSV-1).
  • Treatment of choice = Acyclovir (or valacyclovir, famciclovir).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Azithromycin:

 

  • Used for Chlamydia trachomatis infections, including nongonococcal urethritis and chancroid (Haemophilus ducreyi).
  • Not effective for HSV.

 

Option C. Fluconazole:

 

  • Used for Candida albicans infections (eg, candidal balanitis or vaginitis).
  • Candida causes erythematous patches with curdy white discharge, not ulcers.

 

Option D. Penicillin:

 

  • Used for Treponema pallidum (syphilis), which causes a painless, indurated chancre, not multiple painful ulcers.

choices.text: Double-stranded DNA → double-stranded DNA template → double-stranded DNA progeny
Double-stranded DNA → RNA template → partially double-stranded DNA progeny
Single-stranded DNA → double-stranded DNA template → single-stranded DNA progeny
Single-stranded RNA → double-stranded DNA template → single-stranded RNA progeny

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man comes to the OPD due to 2 months of fatigue, intermittent arthralgias, and poor appetite. Liver aminotransferases are elevated. Hepatitis serology shows the following:

Hepatitis A virus antibody: negative

Hepatitis B surface antibody (HBsAb): negative

Hepatitis B core antibody (HBcAb), total: positive

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg): positive

Hepatitis B E antigen (HBeAg): positive

Hepatitis C virus antibody: negative

Which of the following genome replicative processes is most likely used by the virus infecting this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Double-stranded DNA → RNA template → partially double-stranded DNA progeny

 

  • The patient’s serology:
    • HBsAg positive, HBeAg positive, anti-HBc positive, anti-HBs negative → indicates chronic active Hepatitis B infection.
  • Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a partially double-stranded DNA virus (Hepadnavirus family).
  • Unique replication mechanism:
    1. Viral genome enters nucleus.
    2. Converted to covalently closed circular DNA (cccDNA).
    3. Transcribed by host RNA polymerase II into pregenomic RNA.
    4. Viral reverse transcriptase converts RNA back into DNA.
    5. Produces new virions containing partially double-stranded DNA.

 

This unusual cycle is called reverse transcription DNA virus replication.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2

 

A. BCYE agar → Legionella (1)

 

  • BCYE = Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract agar.
  • Used for isolation of Legionella pneumophila (requires L-cysteine and iron).

 

B. EMJH agar → Leptospira (3)

 

  • EMJH = Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris medium.
  • Specialized medium for culturing Leptospira interrogans.

 

C. PEMBA agar → Bacillus cereus (4)

 

  • PEMBA = Polymyxin Egg Yolk Mannitol Bromothymol Blue Agar.
  • Selective medium for Bacillus cereus (produces bluish colonies with lecithinase activity).

 

D. Butzler’s agar → Campylobacter (2)

 

  • Butzler’s medium is selective for Campylobacter jejuni (contains antibiotics to inhibit competing flora).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a sore on his right hand. The lesion began as a small, painless papule 3 days ago and rapidly enlarged and ulcerated. He is in the wool business and recently returned from a tour of wool-processing plants in several Asian countries. Physical examination is shown below. The toxin causing edema around this patient's ulcer has a mechanism of action most similar to a different toxin produced by which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bordetella pertussis

 

  • The image and clinical history describe cutaneous anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis.
  • Classic lesion: starts as a painless papule → vesicle → ulcer with black eschar and surrounding edema.
  • Occupation: wool/hides exposure → “woolsorter’s disease”.
  • Edema toxin of Bacillus anthracis:
    • Composed of protective antigen + edema factor.
    • Edema factor is an adenylate cyclase → increases intracellular cAMP.
    • This impairs neutrophil function and causes massive edema.
  • A similar toxin mechanism is produced by Bordetella pertussis:
    • Pertussis toxin also increases cAMP, but by ADP-ribosylating Gi protein (inhibits Gi, leading to unopposed adenylate cyclase activity).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: 

 

  • Produces a toxin that inhibits acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junction → flaccid paralysis.
  • Mechanism: blocks SNARE proteins, not related to cAMP.

 

Option C. Clostridium difficile: 

 

  • Toxin A (enterotoxin) and Toxin B (cytotoxin) disrupt actin cytoskeleton by inactivating Rho GTPases → cause colonic mucosal injury and pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Not related to adenylate cyclase.

 

Option D. Shigella dysenteriae:

 

  • Produces Shiga toxin → inactivates 60S ribosomal subunit by cleaving rRNA → inhibits protein synthesis and causes cell death.
  • Not related to cAMP.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man initially comes to his primary care physician with persistent fever, night sweats, and fatigue. Thorough evaluation yields a diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia. While undergoing treatment for his malignancy, the patient comes to the oncologist complaining of headaches, scant nasal discharge, and a problem with his left eye. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the paranasal sinuses in addition to left-sided orbital swelling and cellulitis. Mild proptosis and ptosis of the left eye are also present. Biopsy of his sinus mucosa is shown below. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

  • Patient has CML under treatment → immunocompromised state.
  • Clinical presentation: sinus infection, orbital cellulitis, proptosis, ptosis → invasive fungal sinusitis.
  • Biopsy image shows:
    • Septate hyphae
    • Acute angle (≈45°) branching
      → classic for Aspergillus fumigatus.
  • This is invasive aspergillosis, a life-threatening opportunistic infection in neutropenic or immunosuppressed patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis:

 

  • Dimorphic fungus.
  • Causes broad-based budding yeast in tissues.
  • Pulmonary disease, skin and bone lesions, not invasive sinusitis with septate hyphae.

 

 

Option C. Mucor (Mucormycosis): 

 

  • Also causes invasive sinusitis in immunocompromised (esp. diabetics in ketoacidosis).
  • But histology shows broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching (90°), not narrow septate hyphae with 45° branching.

 

 

Option D. Coccidioides immitis:

 

  • Causes coccidioidomycosis (Valley fever).
  • Tissue form shows spherules with endospores, not hyphae.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Phase contrast microscopy is the technique used to study motility in live bacteria. 
  2. Interferon-beta (IFN-β) is a type I interferon, which is predominantly secreted in response to viral infections. 
  3. Alveolar echinococcosis can mimic HCC on imaging.
  4. Protein A binds the Fc portion of lgG
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

1. Kanagawa phenomenon is seen with V. vulnificus and V. parahaemolyticus: Incorrect. Kanagawa phenomenon (beta-hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar) is seen only with pathogenic strains of Vibrio parahaemolyticus, not with V. vulnificus.

 

2. TLR3 and AXL receptors are associated with Nipah virus: Incorrect.

 

  • TLR3 and AXL are linked with Zika virus entry and recognition, not Nipah.
  • Nipah virus entry is mediated by Ephrin-B2 and Ephrin-B3 receptors.

 

3. Dusting powder can be sterilised by autoclave: Incorrect. Powders are sterilized by dry heat (hot air oven, 160°C for 1 hour), not by autoclave (moist heat), which would cause clumping.

 

4. Schistosomes are monoecious: Incorrect.

 

  • Schistosomes are the only dioecious trematodes (male and female worms separate).
  • Most other trematodes are monoecious.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the physician due to diarrhea for the last 4 months. He visited a student health clinic at his university a month ago and was prescribed a course of antibiotics, but his diarrhea failed to improve. He also has persistent nausea, a bloating sensation, and a 6.8-kg weight loss. Microscopic examination of his stool is shown in the image. Impairment of which of the following immune functions would most likely predispose to this patient's infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secretory IgA production

 

  • The stool image shows Giardia lamblia cyst.
  • Clinical history: chronic diarrhea, bloating, weight loss, non-response to antibiotics → consistent with giardiasis.
  • Giardia infects the small intestine, attaching to the mucosa and causing malabsorption and steatorrhea.
  • Immune defense:
    • The main protective mechanism is secretory IgA in the intestinal mucosa.
    • IgA prevents adherence of Giardia to the mucosal surface.
  • Patients with IgA deficiency or conditions impairing mucosal immunity (eg, X-linked agammaglobulinemia) are predisposed to chronic/recurrent giardiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial killing by neutrophils: Important for pyogenic bacterial infections, not for protozoa like Giardia.

 

Option B. CD8+ T lymphocyte-mediated cytotoxicity: Crucial for viral infections and intracellular pathogens[like T. whipplei, not Giardia (which is extracellular).

 

Option C. Eosinophil-mediated cytotoxicity: Important in helminthic (worm) infections, not protozoan Giardia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a week of fever, dyspnea, and cough with productive, foul-smelling sputum. She underwent an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy 10 days ago for a long history of heartburn. Temperature is 38.7 C°(101.7°F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 108/min, and respirations are 22/min. Dentition is poor. Crackles are heard over the right upper lung field. Complete blood count shows leukocytes of 14,500/mm'. Chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following additional therapies would be most helpful for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clindamycin

 

  • Clinical clues:
    • Recent upper GI endoscopy → risk of aspiration.
    • Poor dentition → anaerobic oral flora colonization.
    • Symptoms: foul-smelling sputum, fever, productive cough, dyspnea.
    • Chest X-ray: consolidation with possible abscess in the right upper lobe (common aspiration site in supine patients).
  • Diagnosis: Aspiration pneumonia with anaerobic lung abscess.
  • Best antibiotic: Clindamycin, because it covers:
    • Anaerobes (Bacteroides, Fusobacterium, Peptostreptococcus).
    • Oral flora (Streptococcus viridans).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ampicillin and gentamicin: Good for Enterococcus and gram-negatives, but poor anaerobic coverage.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: Mainly for gram-negative rods, poor anaerobic and oral flora coverage.

 

Option D. Doxycycline: Broad-spectrum antibiotic, but not reliable for anaerobes in aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text:
Which of the following terms best describes the MacConkey medium?

 

  1. Differential
  2. Enrichment
  3. Transport
  4. Selective
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

MacConkey agar is both differential and selective:

 

Statement 1. Differential:

 

  • Contains lactose and neutral red (pH indicator).
  • Lactose fermenters (eg, E. coli, Klebsiella) → produce pink colonies.
  • Non-lactose fermenters (eg, Salmonella, Shigella, Pseudomonas) → produce colorless colonies.

 

Statement 4. Selective:

 

  • Contains bile salts and crystal violet, which inhibit the growth of gram-positive bacteria.
  • Allows only gram-negative organisms to grow.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. Enrichment medium: Used to enhance growth of fastidious organisms (eg, blood agar, chocolate agar).

 

Statement 3. Transport medium: Used to preserve specimens during transport (eg, Stuart’s, Amies medium). Not the function of MacConkey agar.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to a week of fever, chills, productive cough with yellow-white sputum, and shortness of breath. The patient received an allogenic renal transplantation 6 months ago and currently takes maintenance immunosuppressive therapy. Chest imaging is shown below. Sputum Gram stain and culture are negative. Bronchoalveolar lavage cultures yield light growth of branching, filamentous rods that are partially acid-fast. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nocardiosis

 

  • Patient history:
    • Renal transplant → immunosuppressed.
    • Fever, productive cough, dyspnea with negative Gram stain and culture.
    • CT chest: multiple cavitary lung lesions with consolidation.
  • Bronchoalveolar lavage findings: branching filamentous rods that are partially acid-fast → classic for Nocardia species.
  • Nocardia is an aerobic, gram-positive, weakly acid-fast, branching filamentous bacterium.
  • Common presentation: pulmonary nocardiosis (cavitary pneumonia) in immunocompromised hosts, which may disseminate to the brain and skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB (Mycobacterium tuberculosis): Also causes cavitary lung disease, but organisms are fully acid-fast bacilli, not branching filamentous rods.

 

Option C. Histoplasma:

 

  • Dimorphic fungus, not filamentous branching rods.
  • Associated with Ohio & Mississippi river valleys, and shows yeast in macrophages, not acid-fast filaments.

 

Option D. Mucormycosis

 

  • Broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae on biopsy.
  • Causes rhino-orbital-cerebral disease in diabetics and immunosuppressed, not partially acid-fast rods.

questions.text: The test shown below, which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

  • The image shows a bacitracin sensitivity test on a blood agar plate.
  • A paper disk impregnated with bacitracin (disk A) is placed on the agar.
  • Zone of inhibition around the bacitracin disk = organism is sensitive.
  • Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus):
    • Beta-hemolytic on blood agar.
    • Characteristically bacitracin sensitive → used as a key lab test for identification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: Beta-hemolytic on blood agar, but identification relies on catalase test (positive) and coagulase test (positive).

 

Option C. Clostridium botulinum: Anaerobic spore-forming bacillus; identified using Nagler reaction.

 

Option D. Bacillus: Large gram-positive rods; usually identified by spore staining and other biochemical tests[eg-McFayden’s reaction], not bacitracin sensitivity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the office due to abnormal movements of his arm and face over the last week. The patient has had 1- to 2-minute episodes of jerking and twitching of the left arm and left side of the face. The patient was recently diagnosed with HIV and started antiretroviral therapy 2 months ago. At that time, his CD4 count was 46/mm3. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg, and pulse is 76/min. Left arm motor strength is 4/5, and deep tendon reflexes are 3+. An MRI of the brain is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine

 

  • Patient: HIV-positive with CD4 count 46/mm³ → advanced immunosuppression.
  • Clinical: focal seizures, focal weakness (left-sided).
  • MRI brain: ring-enhancing lesion in basal ganglia (classic finding).
  • Most likely diagnosis: Cerebral toxoplasmosis (Toxoplasma gondii reactivation), the most common CNS infection in AIDS patients with CD4 <100.

 

Treatment:

 

  • First-line = Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Leucovorin (to prevent folate deficiency).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spiramycin: Used in acute Toxoplasma infection during pregnancy to prevent congenital transmission. Not for CNS toxoplasmosis.

 

Option B. Amphotericin B and flucytosine: Used for Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis, which presents with meningitis symptoms, not focal ring-enhancing lesions.

 

Option C. Ganciclovir: Used for Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections (eg, retinitis, colitis, esophagitis). CMV CNS disease causes ventriculoencephalitis, not ring-enhancing focal lesions.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Incubation period of LGV is 10-30days
  2. Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP) was indigenously developed in India for use in malaria.
  3. C.parvum is the most common coccidian parasite to be causing diarhhea in HIV/AIDS.
  4. Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in U797 phosphotransferase
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

Statement 1. Incubation period of LGV is 10–30 days:

 

  • Correct
  • Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1–L3.
  • Incubation period: 10–30 days before inguinal lymphadenitis and buboes appear.

 

Statement 2. Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP) was indigenously developed in India for use in malaria:

 

  • Incorrect.
  • MIP was developed in India as an immunomodulatory vaccine against leprosy and tuberculosis, not malaria.

 

Statement 3. Cryptosporidium parvum is the most common coccidian parasite causing diarrhea in HIV/AIDS:

 

  • Incorrect.
  • The most common coccidian parasite in HIV/AIDS patients with chronic diarrhea is Isospora belli, although Cryptosporidium can also cause severe diarrhea.
  • In many textbooks, Isospora is emphasized as the commonest.

 

Statement 4. Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase:

 

  • Correct.
  • CMV resistance to ganciclovir arises from mutation in UL97 gene, which encodes a viral phosphotransferase needed to phosphorylate ganciclovir for activation.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old student comes to the physician complaining of 4 days of fever, double vision, and painful swelling around his eyes. He also has significant muscle pain in his neck and jaw muscles. Two weeks ago the patient returned from a trip to Goa. One week after his return, he developed abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. These symptoms resolved spontaneously. He has a history of intravenous drug abuse but recently completed a drug rehabilitation program. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min, and respirations are 14/min. Physical examination shows subungual splinter hemorrhages, periorbital edema, and chemosis. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs. The abdomen is soft and nontender without organomegaly. Laboratory results are as follows: 

Mean corpuscular volume: 13.0 g/dL

Platelets: 228,000/mm³

Leukocytes: 10,500/mm³

Neutrophils: 56%

Eosinophils: 22%

Lymphocytes: 23% 

Creatine kinase: 220 U/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichinellosis

 

  • History & exposure: Returned from Goa → likely consumed undercooked pork (common source of Trichinella spiralis).
  • Clinical course:
    • Initial GI symptoms: abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea → due to intestinal phase of infection.
    • Followed by systemic phase: fever, myalgias, periorbital edema, chemosis, and eosinophilia due to muscle invasion by larvae.
    • Subungual splinter hemorrhages can also be seen in trichinellosis (though classic in endocarditis).
  • Labs:
    • Marked eosinophilia (22%).
    • Mild CK elevation → muscle involvement.
  • All of these point to trichinellosis.
  • The following image shows histology of Trichinellosis in a muscle tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascariasis: May cause eosinophilia but usually presents with intestinal obstruction or pulmonary migration symptoms (Löffler’s syndrome), not periorbital edema or myositis.

 

Option B. Dengue fever:

 

  • Presents with fever, myalgia (“breakbone fever”), rash, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.
  • Eosinophilia is not seen; instead, platelets drop, which is normal here.

 

Option D. Infective endocarditis:

 

  • Splinter hemorrhages may suggest this, but there’s no murmur, no bacteremia history, no valve findings.
  • Eosinophilia and periorbital edema do not fit.

questions.text: A 20-year-old farmer presents with firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules on the hairs of the scalp. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piedraia hortae 

 

  • The patient is a farmer with black, gritty, hard nodules firmly attached to scalp hairs.
  • This is classic for Black piedra, a superficial fungal infection.
  • Causative organism: Piedraia hortae, a dematiaceous (dark-pigmented) fungus.
  • The nodules are fungal concretions tightly cemented around the hair shaft.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichosporon:

 

  • Causes White piedra.
  • Presents with soft, white to light-brown nodules loosely attached to hair shafts (beard, mustache, axilla, groin).

 

Option C. Hortaea werneckii:

 

  • Causes Tinea nigra, a superficial infection of the skin.
  • Appears as brown to black macules on palms/soles, not nodules on hair.

 

Option D. Aspergillus niger: Can colonize ear canal and cause otomycosis, not Piedra.

questions.text: What is the intermediate host for the organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No intermediate host

 

  • The image shows Ascaris lumbricoides, the large intestinal roundworm of humans.
  • Mode of transmission: ingestion of embryonated eggs from contaminated food, water, or soil (often raw vegetables).
  • Life cycle:
    • Eggs hatch in small intestine → larvae migrate via bloodstream to lungs → coughed up and swallowed → mature in small intestine.
  • Important point: Ascaris lumbricoides has a direct life cycle, meaning it does not require an intermediate host.
  • Humans are the only definitive host.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vegetables: They serve as a vehicle of transmission (contaminated with eggs), but not as an intermediate host.

 

Option B. Pig: Intermediate host for Taenia solium, not Ascaris.

 

Option C. Cattle: Intermediate host for Taenia saginata, not Ascaris.

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

  • The image shows multiple noduloulcerative lesions along the lymphatic drainage of the leg → classic for sporotrichoid spread (also called lymphocutaneous spread).
  • Characterized by a chain of subcutaneous nodules/ulcers following lymphatics.
  • S. aureus usually causes localized abscesses, cellulitis, or furunculosis.
  • It spreads hematogenously or locally, but does not characteristically spread along lymphatic channels producing sporotrichoid lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Dimorphic fungus, causes Sporotrichosis, classically from rose thorns, sphagnum moss.

 

Option C. Nocardia asteroids: Can cause cutaneous nocardiosis with lymphocutaneous spread.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes “swimming pool granuloma,” spreads along lymphatics.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate  is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

  • The image shows an oxidase test:
    • Positive test → development of a purple color.
    • Negative test → no color change.
  • Clinical setting:
    • Patient with 50% burns develops infection.
    • Burn wound infections are classically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a strict aerobe and oxidase-positive organism. It is MR negative and VP negative, but Catalase positive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella:

 

  • Gram-negative rod, facultative anaerobe.
  • Oxidase negative.
  • Causes pneumonia, UTIs, but not classic burn infections.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli:

 

  • Gram-negative rod, facultative anaerobe.
  • Oxidase negative.
  • Common in UTIs, neonatal meningitis, sepsis.

 

Option D. Salmonella:

 

  • Gram-negative rod, facultative anaerobe.
  • Oxidase negative.
  • Causes gastroenteritis, enteric fever.

choices.text: Bacteria that form biofilms are usually metabolically more active

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about biofilms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacteria that form biofilms are usually metabolically more active

 

  • Biofilms are structured communities of bacteria enclosed in a self-produced glycocalyx (extracellular polysaccharide matrix) and attached to surfaces (prosthetic devices, catheters, teeth, mucosa, etc).

 

Within biofilms:

 

  • Bacteria are usually in a low metabolic state → making them more resistant to antibiotics and host defenses.
  • Biofilms use quorum sensing (cell-to-cell signaling via autoinducers) to coordinate growth, virulence, and detachment.
  • They are responsible for chronic and prosthetic infections (eg, Staphylococcus epidermidis in prosthetic valves/catheters, Pseudomonas in CF lungs, dental plaque).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Responsible for prosthetic infections: True.

 

  • Biofilms are notorious in prosthetic device–related infections (eg, prosthetic heart valves, joint replacements, central venous catheters, urinary catheters, intrauterine devices).
  • Within biofilms, bacteria are resistant to antibiotics and immune responses, leading to chronic, relapsing infections that often require removal of the device.
  • Example organisms:
    • Staphylococcus epidermidis → prosthetic valve endocarditis.
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa → biofilms in cystic fibrosis lungs and on catheters.

 

Option C. Glycocalyx enclosed bacteria: True.

 

  • Biofilm bacteria are embedded in a self-produced extracellular polymeric substance (EPS), often called glycocalyx.
  • This glycocalyx:
    • Protects bacteria from antibiotics, antibodies, and phagocytosis.
    • Provides structural stability and nutrient exchange.
  • Classic example: Streptococcus mutans in dental plaque, producing a glycocalyx from sucrose.

 

Option D. Associated with quorum sensing: True.

 

  • Quorum sensing is the mechanism bacteria use to “talk” to each other via autoinducers (chemical signals).
  • Once a threshold bacterial density is reached, coordinated gene expression occurs → promoting biofilm formation, virulence factor production, and dispersal.
  • Examples:
    • Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses quorum sensing to regulate biofilm thickness and toxin production.
    • Vibrio fischeri uses quorum sensing for bioluminescence (classic model system).

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for the treatment the disease, caused by the organism whose life cycle is shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV Penicillin G

 

  • The diagram (CDC) shows the life cycle of Capillaria hepatica, a nematode parasite.
  • Key features:
    • Adult worms live in the liver of rodents or humans.
    • Eggs are released after host death (decomposition or predation).
    • Transmission occurs via ingestion of embryonated eggs.
  • Human disease: Hepatic capillariasis, which presents with hepatomegaly, fever, eosinophilia, and liver dysfunction.
  • Treatment of choice:
    • IV Penicillin G is recommended as the mainstay treatment.
    • In some cases, adjunctive corticosteroids may be added to control inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral Amoxicillin: Broad-spectrum antibiotic, used for respiratory tract infections but not effective against Capillaria hepatica.

 

Option C. Oral Azithromycin: Macrolide, mainly for bacterial respiratory or STI infections; no role here.

 

Option D. Oral Ampicillin: Beta-lactam antibiotic, used in Listeriosis & Enterococcal infection, not effective for parasitic nematodes.

questions.text: The following test is positive for identification of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida dubliniensis

 

  • The image shows germ tube test under the microscope.
  • Germ tube = filamentous outgrowth produced by yeast cells when incubated in serum at 37°C for 2–3 hours.
  • Positive germ tube test is classically associated with Candida albicans and Candida dubliniensis.

 

Note: C. albicans & Candida dubliniensis are germ-tube–positive species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida glabrata: 

 

  • Germ tube negative.
  • Appears as small budding yeasts; does not form pseudohyphae well.

 

Option C. Candida parapsilosis: 

 

  • Germ tube negative.
  • Typically forms "spider-like" colonies on culture.

 

Option D. Candida tropicalis: 

 

  • Can form pseudohyphae but germ tube negative.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who frequently travels barefoot is suspected to have acquired a parasitic infection via skin penetration. Any of the following parasites may be implicated in this case except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterobius vermicularis

 

  • The patient has infection acquired via skin penetration (walking barefoot).
  • Parasites that penetrate intact skin include:
    • Necator americanus / Ancylostoma duodenale → hookworms, penetrate skin → cause “ground itch,” then migrate to lungs → intestine.
    • Strongyloides stercoralis → filariform larvae penetrate skin → migrate to lungs and intestine.
    • Schistosoma species (eg, S. haematobium) → cercariae penetrate skin while swimming in contaminated freshwater.
  • Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) infection is acquired by ingestion of embryonated eggs, not by skin penetration.

 

Other Options:
