Option B. Necator americanus: Hookworm, acquired by skin penetration, causes iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Strongyloides stercoralis: Larvae penetrate skin, cause autoinfection, hyperinfection in immunocompromised.

 

Option D. Schistosoma haematobium: Cercariae penetrate skin in freshwater, later cause urinary schistosomiasis (hematuria, bladder cancer).

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image showing KOH and LPCB culture morphology:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rhizopus

 

  • The image shows fungal morphology under KOH mount and Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LPCB) stain.
  • Key features visible:
    • Broad, aseptate hyphae (typical of Zygomycetes).
    • Sporangium (round, black structure containing spores).
    • Rhizoids (root-like structures anchoring the hyphae).
  • Rhizopus is differentiated from Mucor by the presence of well-developed rhizoids opposite the sporangiophores.
  • These features confirm the organism as Rhizopus, a common cause of mucormycosis (zygomycosis), especially in diabetics with ketoacidosis and immunocompromised patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Shows acute-angle, septate hyphae and conidial heads, not sporangia with rhizoids.

 

Option B. Mucor: Also has broad, aseptate hyphae and sporangia, but lacks rhizoids (key differentiator from Rhizopus).

 

Option D. Blastomyces: 

 

  • A dimorphic fungus that exists as yeast in tissue (broad-based budding) and mold in environment.
  • Does not produce sporangia or rhizoids.

questions.text: Which of the following sites is used for the influenza virus vaccine production?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Allantoic cavity

 

  • Influenza virus is traditionally grown in embryonated chicken eggs for vaccine production.
  • The allantoic cavity is the preferred site for influenza virus inoculation because:
    • It provides a large fluid-filled space.
    • Virus replicates well and accumulates in the allantoic fluid.
    • Easy to harvest virus in large amounts for vaccine preparation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chorioallantoic membrane (CAM):

 

  • Used for growth of vaccinia virus, herpes simplex virus, variola virus (smallpox).
  • Produces visible pocks/lesions on the membrane.

 

Option B. Suckling mice:

 

  • Used for isolation of certain arboviruses, rabies virus, and coxsackie viruses.
  • Not used for influenza vaccine production.

 

Option C. Primary cell line: Human embryonic kidney (HEK) cells is an example, used in vaccine production and virus cultivation.

questions.text: All of the following are obligate anaerobes except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burkholderia cepaci

 

  • Obligate anaerobes are bacteria that cannot survive in the presence of oxygen because they lack enzymes like superoxide dismutase and catalase.
  • They typically cause foul-smelling infections, abscesses, and gas formation. 
  • Burkholderia cepacia, is a strict aerobic gram-negative bacillus, not an obligate anaerobe.
    • Found in soil and water.
    • Causes opportunistic infections in cystic fibrosis and chronic granulomatous disease patients.

 

Examples of Obligate anaerobes:

 

  • Bacteroides fragilis → intra-abdominal infections.
  • Peptostreptococcus → anaerobic gram-positive cocci in oral/abdominal infections.
  • Prevotella → oral, respiratory, and genital tract infections.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the following virus can be used to prepare vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glycoprotein-G 

 

The image shows the Rabies virus (a bullet-shaped, enveloped virus, family Rhabdoviridae).

 

 Key viral components:

 

  • G (glycoprotein) → forms spikes on the viral envelope, mediates attachment to host cells, and is the primary antigen for neutralizing antibodies. It is used for preparing vaccine.
  • M (matrix protein) → structural, involved in virus budding.[option B]
  • N (nucleocapsid protein) → binds RNA genome, forms ribonucleoprotein complex.[option C]
  • L & P proteins → RNA-dependent RNA polymerase complex for viral transcription.[option D]

 

Rabies vaccines (both inactivated and recombinant) are prepared using purified G glycoprotein, as it induces virus-neutralizing antibodies that confer protection.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the head end as shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D. latum

 

  • The image shows the head end (scolex) of a tapeworm.
  • Key identifying feature:
    • Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) has a scolex with two elongated sucking grooves (bothria) instead of suckers or hooks.
    • This distinguishes it from other cestodes.
  • Clinical association:
    • Causes diphyllobothriasis, acquired from eating raw/undercooked freshwater fish.
    • Can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency → megaloblastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hymenolepis nana (Dwarf tapeworm):

 

  • Scolex has four suckers + rostellum with hooks.
  • Smallest tapeworm infecting humans.

 

 

Option B. Taenia solium (Pork tapeworm): Scolex has four suckers + rostellum armed with hooks (“armed tapeworm”).

 

 

Option C. Echinococcus granulosus:

 

  • Scolex has four suckers + double row of hooks.
  • Causes hydatid cyst disease in humans.

 

 

Summary of heads and proglottids of various cystodes:-

choices.text: Carriers of this disease can be treated with Rifampicin
It can lead to adrenal hemorrhage
Terminal complement deficiency increases the risk of this disease
Azithromycin is the drug of choice

questions.text: A 21-year-old female complains of fever, headache and vomiting from the past 3 days. She has been living in the army recruitment camp for the last three weeks. On examination, she has neck stiffness and petechial rash was noted over the trunk and extremities. Which of the following is false about the disease she's likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azithromycin is the drug of choice

 

Crowded living (camp), acute fever, neck stiffness, petechial rash → classic meningococcal meningitis/septicemia due to Neisseria meningitidis.

 

First-line therapy is IV third-generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime). High-dose penicillin G is an alternative if susceptibility confirmed. Azithromycin is not the drug of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carriers of this disease can be treated with Rifampicin: Rifampin eradicates nasopharyngeal carriage (chemoprophylaxis for close contacts; alternatives: ciprofloxacin, ceftriaxone).

 

Option B. It can lead to adrenal hemorrhage: Can cause Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome (adrenal hemorrhage, shock).

 

Option C. Azithromycin is the drug of choice: Terminal complement (C5–C9) deficiency markedly increases risk of recurrent N. meningitidis infections.

choices.text: It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar
Can be transmitted through soil in bat caves
It doesn’t cause person to person transmission.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient present with chronic fever.  Bone marrow examination of this patient is shown in the given image. Which of the following statement is false about the organism shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

 

  • The image shows Histoplasma capsulatum inside macrophages (small intracellular yeasts with halo).

 

Clinical vignette: Patient with chronic fever, bone marrow involvement → consistent with disseminated histoplasmosis.

 

It cannot be grown in Sabouraud dextrose agar :- False.

 

  • Histoplasma capsulatum can be cultured on Sabouraud dextrose agar.
  • Shows dimorphic nature:
    • Mold form at 25°C (tuberculate macroconidia).
    • Yeast form at 37°C (in tissue, inside macrophages).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spores are infective form: True. Microconidia (spores) inhaled from environment → infective form.

 

Option C. Can be transmitted through soil in bat caves: True. Found in soil enriched with bird or bat droppings (eg, caves → “spelunker’s disease”).

 

Option D. It doesn’t cause person-to-person transmission: True.

  • Spread is only by inhalation of spores from environment.
  • No human-to-human transmission.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

1. Rapid crenation and degeneration of entire cell sheath → Enterovirus (A)

 

  • Enteroviruses cause rapid cell destruction with complete degeneration of the monolayer (“crenation”).

 

2. Large granular lumps resembling bunch of grapes → Adenovirus (B)

 

  • Adenovirus produces large intranuclear inclusions causing clumping of cells that resemble a bunch of grapes.

 

3. Diffuse rounding and ballooning of cell line → HSV (C)

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus infection leads to ballooning degeneration, rounding of cells, and formation of multinucleated giant cells.

 

4. Cytoplasmic vacuolations → SV-40 (D)

 

  • Simian Virus-40 (polyomavirus) typically produces cytoplasmic vacuolation in infected cells (classic vacuolating CPE).

questions.text:
Food poisoning due to which of the following organisms is typically associated with 8-16 hours of incubation period?

 

  1. C. jejuni 
  2. Bacillus cereus - Emetic type
  3. Bacillus cereus - Diarrheal type
  4. Vibrio cholerae
  5. Clostridium perfringens
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 & 5

 

3. Bacillus cereus – Diarrheal type:


Incubation: 8–16 hours.


Due to ingestion of spores, followed by toxin formation in the intestine.
Causes watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

 

5. Clostridium perfringens:


Incubation: 8–16 hours.


Spores germinate in the intestine and produce enterotoxin, leading to watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps.

 

Other Statements:

 

Food poisoning incubation periods vary depending on the toxin versus infection mechanism.

 

1. Campylobacter jejuni: 


Incubation: 1–7 days (not hours).
Causes invasive diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever.

 

2. Bacillus cereus – Emetic type: 


Incubation: 1–6 hours.
Caused by preformed toxin (cereulide) in rice (“fried rice syndrome”).

 

4. Vibrio cholerae: 


Incubation: 24–72 hours.
Causes profuse “rice-water stools.”

 

Educational Objectives:

 

  • Short incubation (less than 6 hours): caused by preformed toxins, e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus emetic type.
  • Intermediate incubation (8–16 hours): toxin produced inside the intestine, e.g., Bacillus cereus diarrheal type, Clostridium perfringens.
  • Long incubation (more than 24 hours): caused by invasive organisms, e.g., Salmonella, Campylobacter, Vibrio.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statements:

 

  1. Kanagawa phenomenon is seen with V.vulnificans and V.parahemolyticus
  2. TLR3 and AXL receptors are associated with Nipah virus. 
  3. Dusting powder can be sterilised by autoclave. 
  4. Schistosomes are monoecious
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

1. Kanagawa phenomenon is seen with V. vulnificus and V. parahaemolyticus: Incorrect. Kanagawa phenomenon (beta-hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar) is seen only with pathogenic strains of Vibrio parahaemolyticus, not with V. vulnificus.

 

 

2. TLR3 and AXL receptors are associated with Nipah virus: Incorrect.

  • TLR3 and AXL are linked with Zika virus entry and recognition, not Nipah.
  • Nipah virus entry is mediated by Ephrin-B2 and Ephrin-B3 receptors.

 

3. Dusting powder can be sterilised by autoclave: Incorrect. Powders are sterilized by dry heat (hot air oven, 160°C for 1 hour), not by autoclave (moist heat), which would cause clumping.

 

4. Schistosomes are monoecious: Incorrect.

 

  • Schistosomes are the only dioecious trematodes (male and female worms separate).
  • Most other trematodes are monoecious.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Miyagawa corpuscles are found in K.granulomatosis
  2. S. sonnei shows late lactose fermentation
  3. B. Cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to  Aminoglycosides and cephalosporins
  4. Cytomegalovirus is the leading cause of infection in renal transplant recipients during the first four months post-transplantation.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

 

2. S. sonnei shows late lactose fermentation: Correct.

 

  • Among Shigella, S. sonnei is a late lactose fermenter (others are typically non-lactose fermenters).

 

3. Burkholderia cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and cephalosporins: Correct.

 

  • BCC exhibits intrinsic resistance to many agents, notably aminoglycosides and several β-lactams/cephalosporins.

 

4. Cytomegalovirus is the leading cause of infection in renal transplant recipients during the first four months: Correct.

 

  • CMV is the most common significant viral infection in the early post-transplant period (especially 1–4 months).

 

Incorrect Statement: 

 

1. Miyagawa corpuscles are found in K. granulomatosis: Incorrect.

 

  • Granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) due to Klebsiella granulomatis shows Donovan bodies (safety-pin intracellular organisms) in macrophages, not Miyagawa corpuscles.
  • “Miyagawa” inclusions are classically described with chlamydial inclusions, not donovanosis.

choices.text: Fruit bats are the natural host

questions.text: A 47-year-old pig farmer presented with fever, headaches, myalgia, and a sore throat. He later develops dizziness, altered consciousness, and seizures.  Identify the false statement regarding the condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No human to human transmission

 

  • The scenario describes Nipah virus infection:
    • Occupation: pig farmer (pig amplification host).
    • Clinical: fever, myalgia, sore throat → encephalitis with seizures, altered consciousness.

 

Epidemiology: outbreaks in South & Southeast Asia. No human to human transmission – False statement regarding Nipah virus.

 

  • Nipah virus can spread human-to-human, particularly via respiratory secretions and in healthcare settings.
    • Documented in outbreaks in Bangladesh and India

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Causative organism is a paramyxovirus: True. Nipah virus belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family, genus Henipavirus.

 

Option B. Pigs are the intermediate hosts: True. Fruit bats (Pteropus) are the natural reservoir, while pigs act as intermediate/amplifying hosts.

 

Option D. Fruit bats are the natural host: True. Pteropus fruit bats are the reservoir hosts, shedding virus in saliva, urine, and excreta.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

  • The image shows histopathology of the duodenum with trophozoites attached to the mucosal surface.
  • These trophozoites have a pear/teardrop shape with 2 nuclei (“face-like” appearance).
  • Classic clinical presentation:
    • Chronic watery diarrhea
    • Steatorrhea (fat malabsorption)
    • Common in immunocompromised patients (eg, HIV)

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes flask-shaped ulcers in colon and amoebic liver abscess, not chronic watery diarrhea with duodenal pathology.

 

 

Option C. Microsporidia:

 

  • Opportunistic infection in HIV.
  • Shows small intracellular spores within enterocytes, not trophozoites on mucosal surface.

 

 

Option D. Cryptosporidia:

 

  • Acid-fast oocysts seen on stool microscopy.
  • On biopsy, organisms appear as small intracellular but extracytoplasmic forms attached to the brush border.

questions.text:
For which of the following parasites is NNN medium used for isolation?

 

  1. Leishmania donovani
  2. Giardia
  3. E. histolytica
  4. Trichomonas vaginalis
  5. Trypanosoma cruzi
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 5

 

NNN medium (Novy–MacNeal–Nicolle medium):

 

  • A biphasic medium (blood agar slant + liquid overlay).
  • Specifically designed for the cultivation of hemoflagellates.
  • Supports the growth of parasites that exist in both intracellular and extracellular forms.

 

Parasites grown in NNN medium:

 

1. Leishmania donovani:

 

  • Cultured in NNN medium.
  • Amastigotes (in tissue) transform into promastigotes in culture.
  • Used in the diagnosis of kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis).

 

5. Trypanosoma cruzi:

 

  • Can also be grown in NNN medium.
  • Useful for research and diagnosis in chronic Chagas disease.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

2. Giardia lamblia: Cultured in Diamond’s medium, not NNN.

 

3. Entamoeba histolytica: Cultured in Locke-egg serum medium or Robinson’s medium.

 

4. Trichomonas vaginalis: Cultured in Diamond’s medium.

questions.text: Which method is typically not used to determine the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of an antibiotic?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Disk diffusion method

 

  • MIC (Minimum Inhibitory Concentration): the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial that prevents visible growth of a microorganism.

 

Disk diffusion method (Kirby-Bauer test) – Not used for MIC.

 

  • Provides zone of inhibition diameter to classify as Sensitive/Intermediate/Resistant.
  • Does not give an exact MIC value, only a qualitative result.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gradient diffusion method (E-test): Used.

 

  • Antibiotic-impregnated strip with gradient concentrations placed on agar.
  • Elliptical zone of inhibition intersects strip → MIC value read directly.

 

 

Option B. Broth microdilution method: Used.

 

  • Serial dilutions of antibiotic in broth with organism inoculated.
  • The lowest concentration with no visible growth = MIC.

 

 

Option D. Agar dilution method: Used.

 

  • Antibiotics incorporated into agar plates at different concentrations.
  • Growth or no growth checked → MIC determined.

 

 

NPs: Nanoparticles.

choices.text: To facilitate horizontal gene transfer between bacterial cells
To enable bacteria to resist viral infections through sequence-specific DNA cleavage
To allow the incorporation of viral DNA into the bacterial genome
To protect bacteria from the eukaryotic immune system

questions.text: What is the primary function of the CRISPR system in bacteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To enable bacteria to resist viral infections through sequence-specific DNA cleavage

 

  • CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) is part of the adaptive immune system in bacteria and archaea.
  • Function:
    • When a bacterium is infected by a virus (phage), it can incorporate fragments of viral DNA into its CRISPR array.
    • These sequences are later transcribed into CRISPR RNAs (crRNAs).
    • crRNAs guide Cas nucleases to recognize and cleave complementary viral DNA sequences during future infections.
    • This provides sequence-specific protection against phages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To facilitate horizontal gene transfer between bacterial cells – Incorrect. This is mainly done by conjugation, transformation, or transduction, not CRISPR.

 

Option C. To allow the incorporation of viral DNA into the bacterial genome – Incorrect. That’s more like lysogeny by temperate bacteriophages, not CRISPR function.

 

Option D. To protect bacteria from the eukaryotic immune system – Incorrect. CRISPR does not target eukaryotic immunity; it specifically defends against phage/foreign nucleic acids.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the outpatient department with a 10-day history of abdominal pain, intermittent diarrhea, and mild weight loss. Her family reports no significant travel history or exposure to pets. Stool microscopy reveals eggs characteristic of a specific helminth infection shown below. Given this diagnosis, what is the most appropriate treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Praziquantel

 

  • The image shows a characteristic H.nana egg.
  • Treatment:
    • Praziquantel is the drug of choice for all cestodes infection. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Albendazole:

 

  • Used for nematodes (roundworms): Ascaris, Hookworm, Trichuris, Enterobius, etc.
  • Not effective for cestodes.

 

Option B. Mebendazole: Also used for intestinal nematodes, not the treatment of choice for cestodes.

 

Option D. Pyrantel pamoate: Effective against nematodes (Enterobius, Ascaris, hookworms).

questions.text: A 45-year-old postrenal transplant patient presents with diarrhea three months after the transplant. Stool microscopy reveals spherical organisms that are Kinyoun stain positive. Epifluorescence microscopy is shown. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyclospora

 

  • Patient is a post-renal transplant immunocompromised individual with diarrhea.
  • Stool microscopy shows spherical oocysts that are:
    • Kinyoun acid-fast stain positive (variable staining).
    • Show blue-green autofluorescence under epifluorescence microscopy (seen in the given image).
  • These are classic for Cyclospora infection.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Balantidium coli:

 

  • The only ciliate protozoan parasite of humans.
  • Large trophozoites with cilia; not acid-fast, not autofluorescent.

 

 

Option C. Cystoisospora belli (formerly Isospora belli):

 

  • Oocysts are ellipsoidal (oval), not spherical.
  • Acid-fast positive but do not show the same type of autofluorescence pattern as Cyclospora.

 

 

Option D. Cryptosporidium hominis:

 

  • Oocysts are spherical and acid-fast positive.
  • But typically smaller (4–6 µm) compared to Cyclospora (8–10 µm).

questions.text: A 54-year-old man from the Northeastern States presents to the clinic with a 1-week history of fever, fatigue, and myalgia. Physical examination reveals mild jaundice, and laboratory tests show hemolytic anemia. A peripheral blood smear is performed, revealing the following. Based on the patient's history, clinical presentation, and the peripheral blood smear findings, which vector is most likely involved in the spread of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ixodid tick

 

  • The image shows a peripheral blood smear with intraerythrocytic ring forms and Maltese cross (tetrad) formations.
  • This is diagnostic of Babesiosis, caused by Babesia microti (in the United States, including Northeastern states).
  • Clinical: fever, fatigue, myalgia, hemolytic anemia, and sometimes mild jaundice.
  • Transmission:
    • Vector: Ixodes scapularis (Ixodid tick) – the same tick that transmits Lyme disease (Borrelia burgdorferi) and Anaplasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anopheles: Vector for malaria (Plasmodium spp.), but the smear here does not show malaria morphology (no schizonts, gametocytes).

 

Option C. Louse: Vector for epidemic typhus (Rickettsia prowazekii), not babesiosis.

 

Option D. Sandfly: Vector for Leishmania spp., which cause visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fever, hypotension, and skin rash. She had a tampon in situ for 24 hours. A bacterial cause is suspected. Which of the following toxin is not involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exfoliative toxin

 

The patient has Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS), classically associated with tampon use and Staphylococcus aureus.

 

  • Clinical: fever, hypotension, rash, multi-organ involvement.

 

The main toxins involved are superantigens that cause massive T-cell activation and cytokine release. 

 

Exfoliative toxin –  Not involved in TSS

 

  • Produced by S. aureus.
  • Causes staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), not toxic shock.
  • Acts by cleaving desmoglein-1 in epidermis → skin peeling.

 

Toxins in TSS:

 

  • Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) → most important cause in menstrual TSS.[option B]
  • Staphylococcal enterotoxins (A, B, C, etc.) → can also act as superantigens in non-menstrual TSS.[option A]
  • Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (SPE A, C) → responsible for streptococcal TSS.[option D]

questions.text:
Which of the following features are characteristic of the Anopheles mosquito?

 

  1. Stripes on wings
  2. Larva rests at an angle to water surface
  3. Adult rests at an angle to the surface of the skin
  4. Eggs laid in clusters
  5. No siphon tube in larvae
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 5

 

3. Adult rests at an angle to the surface of the skin: True.

 

  • Adult Anopheles rests at a 45° angle to the surface.
  • In contrast, Culex and Aedes rest parallel to the surface.

 

5. No siphon tube in larvae: True.

 

  • Anopheles larvae lack a siphon tube and hence lie flat on the water surface.
  • Culex and Aedes larvae possess siphon tubes.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

1. Stripes on wings: False.

 

  • Characteristic of Culex and Aedes mosquitoes (e.g., Aedes has spotted wings).
  • Anopheles has dappled wings with discrete dark and pale spots, not uniform stripes.

 

2. Larva rests at an angle to water surface: False.

 

  • Anopheles larva lies parallel to the water surface (no siphon tube).
  • Culex and Aedes larvae rest at an angle because they have a siphon tube.

 

4. Eggs laid in clusters: False.

 

  • Anopheles lays eggs singly, boat-shaped with lateral floats.
  • Culex lays eggs in rafts/clusters.

questions.text: A laboratory researcher is studying the pathogenesis of Staphylococcus aureus and focuses on the toxins that contribute to its virulence. One group of toxins has been noted to have synergistic hemolytic activity on sheep blood agar when combined with other staphylococcal hemolysins. Which toxin is known for this synergistic activity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Panton-Valentine leukocidin

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus produces multiple toxins that contribute to its virulence.
  • Panton-Valentine leukocidin (PVL):
    • A bicompoment pore-forming toxin.
    • Causes destruction of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (neutrophils) and macrophages.
    • Notable for synergistic hemolytic activity with other hemolysins on sheep blood agar.
    • Clinically associated with severe skin and soft tissue infections and necrotizing pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha toxin:

 

  • Cytolysin that forms pores in cell membranes.
  • Causes hemolysis, dermonecrosis, and tissue injury.
  • Not specifically associated with synergistic hemolysis.

 

Option B. Beta toxin:

 

  • Sphingomyelinase (toxic for RBCs, fibroblasts, leukocytes).
  • Causes "hot-cold" hemolysis phenomenon.
  • Not the one classically associated with synergism.

 

Option C. Delta toxin:

 

  • Small peptide toxin with surfactant-like activity.
  • Causes cytolysis, but not synergistic hemolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses will not need RT-PCR for its detection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Simian 40

 

  • RT-PCR (Reverse Transcriptase PCR) is required only for RNA viruses, because RNA must first be converted into complementary DNA before amplification.
  • SV40 is a DNA virus (double-stranded DNA, Polyomaviridae family), so it can be detected directly by standard PCR without the need for reverse transcriptase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebola virus:

 

  • Single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus (Filoviridae).
  • Requires RT-PCR for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Rabies virus:

 

  • Single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae).
  • Requires RT-PCR for detection.

 

Option D. Vesicular stomatitis virus:

 

  • Single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus (Rhabdoviridae, same family as rabies).
  • Requires RT-PCR for detection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of fever, headache, and a persistent dry cough. He mentions that his symptoms started a few days after he was cleaning an old, abandoned aviary. His physical examination is unremarkable except for mild respiratory distress. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing interstitial infiltrates. Laboratory investigations, including serology, indicate atypical pneumonia with inclusion bodies suggestive of a zoonotic infection. Based on these findings, the physician is considering the diagnosis of a specific zoonotic atypical pneumonia. Which inclusion body is most likely associated with this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leventhal Cole Lillie bodies

 

  • The patient has atypical pneumonia after exposure to an aviary (birds) → points toward Chlamydophila psittaci infection (Psittacosis / Ornithosis).
  • In C. psittaci infection, characteristic Leventhal-Cole-Lillie (LCL) bodies are seen:
    • These are inclusion bodies found within infected cells.
  • Radiology often shows interstitial pneumonia.
  • It is a zoonosis transmitted from birds to humans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Henderson-Patterson bodies:

 

  • Found in Molluscum contagiosum (poxvirus infection).
  • Large eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions.
  • Not related to atypical pneumonia.

 

Option B. Miyagawa corpuscles:

 

  • Seen in Chlamydia trachomatis infections.
  • Cytoplasmic inclusions, but not specific for psittacosis.

 

Option D. Negri bodies:

 

  • Found in Rabies virus infection.
  • Eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons (esp. hippocampus & Purkinje cells).

questions.text: During a surgical rotation, a medical student observes that a patient with a deep skin infection has rapid spreading of the infection through the fascial planes. The attending physician explains that certain bacterial exoenzymes facilitate the spread of infection by degrading connective tissue components. Which Streptococcus exoenzyme is primarily responsible for the breakdown of connective tissue, contributing to the spread of the infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyaluronidase

 

  • Streptococcus pyogenes produces several exoenzymes and exotoxins that enhance virulence.
  • Hyaluronidase:
    • Breaks down hyaluronic acid, an important component of connective tissue and ground substance.
    • This allows bacteria to spread rapidly along fascial planes, contributing to conditions like necrotizing fasciitis.
    • Often referred to as the "spreading factor".

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptolysin O:

 

  • Oxygen-labile hemolysin.
  • Causes β-hemolysis on blood agar and is antigenic → detected by ASO titers.
  • Role: cytotoxicity, not tissue spread.

 

Option C. Streptolysin S:

 

  • Oxygen-stable hemolysin.
  • Causes hemolysis, cytotoxicity, but does not contribute significantly to connective tissue breakdown.

 

Option D. Streptococcus pyogenic exotoxin (SPE):

 

  • Superantigen causing massive cytokine release, responsible for scarlet fever rash and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.
  • Not directly involved in tissue breakdown.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with diabetes presents with a tender swelling on his forehead. Incision and drainage yield foul-smelling pus that fluoresces red under ultraviolet light. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacteroides spp.

 

  • The case describes a foul-smelling abscess in a diabetic patient → strongly suggests an anaerobic infection.
  • Key clue: pus fluoresces red under ultraviolet (UV) light.
  • This fluorescence is a diagnostic feature of Bacteroides spp. (especially Bacteroides fragilis group) due to production of porphyrins that fluoresce red.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Peptostreptococcus spp: 

 

  • Also anaerobes associated with foul-smelling pus.
  • But they do not produce red fluorescence under UV light.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

 

  • Produces pigments: pyocyanin (blue-green) and pyoverdine (yellow-green, fluorescent under UV).
  • Causes greenish-blue pus, not red fluorescence.

 

Option D. Acanthamoeba spp:

 

  • Free-living amoeba causing keratitis (esp. in contact lens wearers) and granulomatous encephalitis.
  • Not associated with foul-smelling pus or fluorescence.

choices.text: A microorganism should be constantly associated with the lesions of the disease
It should be possible to isolate the bacterium in pure culture from the lesions
Inoculation of such pure culture into laboratory animals should reproduce the lesions
Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases

questions.text: All are Koch’s postulates except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Administration of broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent dependably eradicates the organisms and cures the diseases

 

  • Koch’s postulates are classical criteria used to establish the causal relationship between a microorganism and a disease.
  • They include:
    1. The microorganism is found in all cases of the disease.
    2. It can be isolated in pure culture.
    3. Inoculation of this pure culture into a susceptible host reproduces the disease.
    4. The same organism can be re-isolated from the experimentally infected host.
  • Statement D is not one of Koch’s postulates; it refers instead to a therapeutic principle (antimicrobial eradication), not proof of causation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A microorganism should be constantly associated with the lesions of the disease: This is Koch’s first postulate → establishing consistent presence of the microorganism in diseased cases.

 

Option B. It should be possible to isolate the bacterium in pure culture from the lesions: Koch’s second postulate → laboratory isolation in pure culture.

 

Option C. Inoculation of such pure culture into laboratory animals should reproduce the lesions: Koch’s third postulate → reproduction of the disease in experimental hosts.

questions.text: A farmer presenting with fever off and on for the past 4 years was diagnosed to be suffering from chronic brucellosis. All of the following serological tests would be helpful in the diagnosis at this state except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Standard Agglutination test

 

  • In chronic brucellosis, the antibody profile shifts:
    • Early disease → mainly IgM antibodies, detected by Standard Agglutination Test (SAT).
    • Chronic disease → mainly IgG antibodies, which do not agglutinate well in SAT.
  • Therefore, SAT is not reliable in chronic cases.
  • Tests that detect IgG antibodies (such as Coomb’s test, 2-Mercaptoethanol test, and Complement Fixation Test) are more useful in chronic disease.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. 2-Mercaptoethanol (2-ME) Test:

 

  • 2-ME destroys IgM antibodies but leaves IgG antibodies intact.
  • Since chronic brucellosis is characterized by IgG predominance, this test helps identify persistent infection by measuring IgG levels.
  • Useful to differentiate acute (IgM) vs chronic (IgG) infection.

 

Option C. Complement Fixation Test (CFT):

 

  • Detects mainly IgG antibodies (fix complement effectively).
  • In chronic brucellosis, when IgM has declined, CFT remains positive because of IgG.
  • Often used to monitor treatment response and disease progression.

 

Option D. Coombs (Antiglobulin) Test:

 

  • Detects non-agglutinating IgG antibodies that standard agglutination tests may miss.
  • Very useful in chronic or relapsed brucellosis, when SAT can be falsely negative because IgG does not agglutinate well.
  • Helps confirm longstanding disease.

questions.text: A 2-week-old boy is brought to the OPD due to runny nose, low-grade fever, and skin rash for 2 days. The patient was born at 38 weeks gestation to a 19-year-old woman who had poor access to prenatal care. Temperature is 38° C (100.4° F). Vital signs are otherwise normal for age. On examination, the patient has nasal drainage and peeling skin on his face, hands, and feet. Hepatosplenomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy are present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

  • A 2-week-old newborn with:
    • Runny nose (called snuffles in congenital syphilis).
    • Peeling skin on face, hands, and feet.
    • Hepatosplenomegaly + generalized lymphadenopathy.
  • These are classic signs of early congenital syphilis, usually presenting within the first 2 months of life.
  • Caused by transplacental transmission of Treponema pallidum.
  • Other possible features: rash (esp. palms and soles), osteochondritis, anemia, failure to thrive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythema multiforme:

 

  • Hypersensitivity reaction (often due to HSV, Mycoplasma).
  • Presents with target lesions on skin, not peeling skin + hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Option B. Kawasaki disease:

 

  • Vasculitis in children, usually <5 years.
  • Presents with ≥5 days fever, mucosal changes (strawberry tongue), conjunctivitis, rash, cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • Not typical in a 2-week-old infant.

 

Option C. Measles:

 

  • Presents with high fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and then maculopapular rash.
  • Not associated with peeling skin in a neonate, and too young (maternal antibodies usually protect for first 6 months).

questions.text: An isolate from a cancer patient in the critical care unit is found to be resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides and sensitive to cotrimoxazole, ticarcillin-clavulanic acid. What is the likely microorganism involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stenotrophomonas maltophila

 

  • Bacteria resistant to:carbapenems (eg, meropenem), aminoglycosides, and many β-lactams but Sensitive to cotrimoxazole (drug of choice), and often to ticarcillin–clavulanic acid, is suggestive of Sternotrophomonas maltophilia.
  • Stenotrophomonas maltophilia is a non-fermenting Gram-negative bacillus that causes opportunistic infections, especially in:
    • Critically ill patients
    • Cancer / chemotherapy patients
    • Ventilator-associated pneumonia, bloodstream infections
    • Resistance pattern mentioned above is very characteristic.

questions.text: Select the one which doesn’t cause Urethritis in males:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haemophilus ducreyi

 

  • Urethritis in males is commonly caused by sexually transmitted pathogens like Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, Trichomonas vaginalis, Mycoplasma genitalium, Ureaplasma urealyticum.
  • Haemophilus ducreyi, however, does not cause urethritis.
    • It is the causative agent of chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by:
      • Painful genital ulcers
      • Painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes)
    • It does not involve the urethra or cause urethral discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomoniasis: 

 

  • Caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Can cause nongonococcal urethritis in men → dysuria, mild discharge.

 

Option C. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars D–K) is a leading cause of nongonococcal urethritis.

 

Option D. Gonococcus: Neisseria gonorrhoeae → classic cause of purulent urethritis in men.

questions.text: A young male patient with urethral discharge showed up. Pus cells were discovered after a urine analysis, but no organisms. Which approach is ideal for cultures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) McCoy Cell Line

 

  • Clinical case: male with urethritis, pus cells present in urine but no organisms seen on Gram stain.
  • This is a classic description of nongonococcal urethritis (NGU) caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular bacterium → cannot grow on routine artificial culture media.
  • Best culture method: growth in McCoy cell line (or other susceptible cell lines) followed by detection of inclusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thayer-Martin Medium:

 

  • Chocolate agar with antibiotics (VCN = vancomycin, colistin, nystatin).
  • Selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Would be useful if organisms were seen on Gram stain, but not for Chlamydia.

 

Option C. Lowenstein-Jensen (L.J.) medium:

 

  • Used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture.
  • Not for Chlamydia or urethritis pathogens.

 

Option D. Levinthal Medium:

 

  • Special medium used for Haemophilus influenzae, requiring X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors.
  • Not relevant in urethritis.

questions.text:
True about cholera: 

 

  1. There’s no role of mass prophylaxis in cholera outbreak
  2. Dukoral vaccine can be given for age less than 2 years
  3. Dukoral vaccine is Monovalent
  4. Shanchol Vaccine is Bivalent 
  5. Gastric buffer is added in shanchol vaccine 
  6. 5% Cresol is used for disinfecting Feces, vomitus during outbreaks
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4, 6

 

1. There’s no role of mass prophylaxis in cholera outbreak → True.

 

  • WHO does not recommend mass chemoprophylaxis during outbreaks due to risk of resistance.
  • Focus is on case management, safe water, sanitation, and selective vaccination.

 

3. Dukoral vaccine is Monovalent → True.

 

  • Contains Vibrio cholerae O1 only → monovalent.

 

4. Shanchol vaccine is Bivalent → True.

 

  • Killed oral vaccine containing V. cholerae O1 and O139 → bivalent.

 

6. 5% Cresol is used for disinfecting feces, vomitus during outbreaks → True.

 

  • Standard disinfectant recommended during cholera outbreaks.

 

Other statement:

 

2. Dukoral vaccine can be given for age less than 2 years → False.

 

  • Dukoral (oral, killed whole-cell + recombinant B subunit vaccine) is licensed for ≥2 years only.
  • Not given below 2 years.

 

5. Gastric buffer is added in Shanchol vaccine → False.

 

  • Buffer is required for Dukoral (because of B subunit).
  • Shanchol does not require buffer.

questions.text: Farmer presents with the features of high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting and diarrhea and hypotension. Which stain will help in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wayson’s stain

 

  • The farmer presents with high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), vomiting, diarrhea, hypotension → classic features of plague (Yersinia pestis).
  • Diagnosis is supported by Wayson’s stain, which shows:
    • Safety-pin appearance of Yersinia pestis (bipolar staining with a clear central area).
  • This stain is therefore highly useful in rapid presumptive diagnosis of plague.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neisser stain: Used for demonstrating metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

 

Option C. Albert’s stain: Also used for Corynebacterium diphtheriae, highlighting metachromatic granules (green bacilli with blue/black granules).

 

 

Option D. McFadyean’s stain: Used in Bacillus anthracis to demonstrate the polypeptide capsule (appears as purple capsule on a blue bacillus background).

questions.text: Which of the following species of hemophilus requires only factor X for growth?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemophilus ducreyi

 

Haemophilus Growth Factors

 

  • Factor X = Hemin (heat-stable)
    • An iron-containing porphyrin.
    • Required for synthesis of cytochromes and enzymes involved in electron transport.
    • Found in blood (RBCs → hemoglobin breakdown).
  • Factor V = NAD / NADP (heat-labile)
    • Functions as a coenzyme in redox reactions.
    • Not synthesized by Haemophilus species.
    • Supplied by other bacteria (eg, Staphylococcus aureus → “satellite phenomenon”) or enriched media.

 

H. ducreyi → requires only factor X (causes chancroid).

 

H. influenzae → requires both X and V factors.

 

H. parainfluenzae → requires only factor V.

 

H. paraphrophilus → requires neither (can grow without X and V).

questions.text:
Advantages of Saline wet mount over iodine wet mount is/are?

 

  1. Demonstration of motility of trophozoites
  2. Identify the internal structures of the cyst
  3. Differentiate bile stained vs non bile stained eggs
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & C

 

  • Saline wet mount:
    • Demonstrates motility of trophozoites (since iodine kills motility).
    • Differentiates bile-stained vs non-bile-stained eggs.
  • Iodine wet mount:
    • Kills trophozoites, hence no motility seen.
    • Better for identifying internal structures of cysts (iodine stains glycogen and nuclei).

 

Option B. Identifying the internal structures of the cyst is an advantage of IODINE mount not SALINE mount.

 

Image below shows IODINE and SALINE mount respectively:

questions.text: A 25-year-old female complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage since 2 years. Biopsy is taken and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely responsible organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspergillus fumigatus 

 

  • The biopsy image shows septate hyphae with dichotomous acute-angle branching and conidial heads characteristic of Aspergillus species.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Young female with recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockage for 2 years.
    • This strongly suggests Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (AFRS) or chronic fungal sinusitis.
  • Among Aspergillus spp., A. fumigatus is the most common cause of fungal sinusitis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus niger:

 

  • Can cause otomycosis (fungal ear infection).
  • Less common in chronic sinusitis compared to A. fumigatus.

 

Option C. Mucor: 

 

  • Causes mucormycosis (esp. in diabetics with ketoacidosis, immunocompromised).
  • Shows broad, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. Their sporangiospores are devoid of Rhizoids as shown. [Compare mucor with Rhizopus and Absidia]:

 

 

Option D. Aspergillus flavus: 

 

  • Can cause invasive aspergillosis and sinusitis, but less common than A. fumigatus.
  • Also known for aflatoxin production (hepatocellular carcinoma risk).

 

Comparison of Aspergillus species:

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes with complaints of intermittent bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks after consuming street food during his travel. He is febrile and has RUQ tenderness. Which of the following is the infective form of the likely protozoan causing this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mature quadrinucleate cyst   

 

  • The case:
    • Bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks, history of street food consumption → suggests amoebic dysentery.
    • Right upper quadrant tenderness → points to amoebic liver abscess (complication of Entamoeba histolytica).
  • Life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica:
    • Infective form → Mature quadrinucleate cyst (4 nuclei).
    • Acquired through fecal–oral route, contaminated food or water.
    • Cyst survives stomach acid → excystation in small intestine → releases trophozoites → invade colon (causing dysentery) or spread to liver (abscess).
    • Trophozoite → diagnostic stage (in stool, in tissues), but not infective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trophozoite:

 

  • Motile, invasive form found in tissues and fresh stool.
  • Responsible for clinical disease (ulceration, abscess).
  • Not infective, as it cannot survive gastric acidity.

 

Option C. Metacyclic trophozoite:

 

  • Seen in Trypanosoma (not Entamoeba).
  • Infective stage of trypanosomes transmitted by vectors (eg, tsetse fly).

 

Option D. Precyst:

 

  • Transitional stage before cyst formation.
  • Not infective; must mature into quadrinucleate cyst.

questions.text: Identify the staining method for a tissue biopsy of the painless ulcer shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levaditi's method 

 

  • The clinical image shows a painless genital ulcer, which is the primary chancre of syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • T. pallidum is a spirochete → very thin, spiral-shaped bacterium, not visible on routine Gram stain.
  • Special stains and techniques are required:

 

Levaditi's method

 

  • A silver impregnation stain.
  • Commonly used to demonstrate spirochetes (eg, Treponema pallidum) in tissue sections of EXUDATE SMEAR.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fontana’s method: Another silver impregnation method, used to demonstrate spirochetes as well, but less commonly used for T. pallidum in biopsy tissue.

 

 

Option C. Castaneda’s method:

 

  • Culture method used for Brucella (blood culture bottles with biphasic medium).
  • Not related to spirochetes.

 

 

Option D. Albert’s method: Used to demonstrate metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: Which of the following is a pigment-producing species of mycobacteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) M. scrofulaceum 

 

  • Some non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) produce pigments (carotenoid-like), and classification is based on Runyon’s groups:

 

Pigment-producing groups:

 

  • Photochromogens (Group I): Produce pigment only on exposure to light.
    • Examples: M. kansasii, M. marinum.
  • Scotochromogens (Group II): Produce pigment even in the dark.
    • Examples: M. scrofulaceum, M. gordonae.

 

Nonchromogens (Group III): Do not produce pigment.

 

  • Examples: M. avium-intracellulare complex, M. ulcerans, M. xenopi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. M. ulcerans:

 

  • Causes Buruli ulcer.
  • Nonchromogen → does not produce pigment.

 

Option C. M. avium-intracellulare complex (MAC):

 

  • Causes disseminated disease in AIDS patients.
  • Nonchromogen.

 

Option D. M. xenopi: 

 

  • Causes pulmonary disease.
  • Nonchromogen.

questions.text:
Identify the microaerophilic bacteria from the list: 

 

  1. Positive CLO test. 
  2. Gram-negative bacilli implicated in GBS
  3. Gram-negative curved bacilli with 'fish-in-stream' appearance 
  4. Bacteria showing 'mercury drop' colonies. 
  5. LJ medium showing ruff, buff, tough colonies.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2   

 

Microaerophilic Bacteria:

 

  • Microaerophiles are organisms that require oxygen for survival, but at a lower concentration (5–10%) than atmospheric levels (21%).
  • Too much oxygen is toxic for them (due to lack of complete detoxifying enzymes like catalase, superoxide dismutase).
  • They often colonize environments with reduced oxygen tension, e.g. GI tract, genital tract.

 

1. Positive CLO test → Helicobacter pylori:

 

  • CLO = Campylobacter-like organism test, a rapid urease test.
  • H. pylori is a curved, Gram-negative bacillus, strongly urease positive.
  • Requires microaerophilic conditions (5% O₂, 10% CO₂, 85% N₂).
  • Clinical association → Peptic ulcers, gastritis, gastric carcinoma.

 

2. Gram-negative bacilli implicated in GBS → Campylobacter jejuni:

 

  • Leading cause of bacterial gastroenteritis (GBS = Guillain-Barré Syndrome, post-infectious complication).
  • Curved, comma-shaped, motile, Gram-negative bacilli.
  • Requires microaerophilic atmosphere and grows best at 42°C.
  • Classic “gull-wing” appearance on microscopy.

 

Other statements:

 

3. Gram-negative curved bacilli with "fish-in-stream" appearance → Vibrio cholerae:

 

  • Facultative anaerobe, not microaerophilic.
  • “Fish-in-stream” motility seen in hanging drop prep.
  • Causes cholera with rice-water stools.

 

4. Bacteria showing “mercury drop” colonies → Bordetella pertussis:

 

  • Small, Gram-negative coccobacillus.
  • Colonies on Bordet-Gengou agar resemble mercury drops.
  • Strict aerobe, not microaerophilic.

 

5. LJ medium showing “rough, buff, tough” colonies → Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

 

  • Obligate aerobe, grows best in high O₂ tension.
  • Not microaerophilic.

choices.text: Resistant to El Tor phage V
Not susceptible to group IV phage

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of EI Tor vibrio?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Resistant to El Tor phage V   

 

The El Tor biotype of Vibrio cholerae O1 has distinct laboratory characteristics compared to the classical biotype. 

 

El Tor phage V → El Tor strains are susceptible, not resistant 

 

  • Classical strains are resistant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intrinsic resistance to polymyxin B: Classical strains are sensitive.

 

Option C. Voges-Proskauer test positive: Classical strains are negative.

 

Option  D. Not susceptible to group IV phage: Classical strains are lysed by group IV cholera phage.

 

Summary Table: Classical vs El Tor Biotype

questions.text: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporangiophore

 

Sporangiophore is not a spore but a specialized hyphal stalk that bears asexual spores (sporangiospores).Hence, it is not a sexual spore

 

Sexual spores are formed after fusion of nuclei (karyogamy + meiosis) in fungi.

 

 

  • Main sexual spores include:
    1. Zygospore → formed by fusion of two similar gametangia (Zygomycetes).
    2. Ascospore → formed inside an ascus (Ascomycetes).
    3. Basidiospore → formed on basidium (Basidiomycetes).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zygospore: True sexual spore, seen in Zygomycetes (Rhizopus, Mucor).

 

Option C. Basidiospore: Sexual spore produced externally on a basidium, seen in mushrooms, smuts, rusts.

 

Option D. Ascospore: Sexual spore produced inside an ascus, typical of Ascomycetes (Saccharomyces, Aspergillus).
